div.p: Acted at the Cock-pit, by his MAjESTIES Servants, Anno 1632.
LONDON Printed for RICHARD MARRIOT, and THO. DRING, and are to be sold at their Shops in Fleet-street, 1653.

list.item: SIR Andrew Mendicant, an old Knight, turnd a projector.
Mr. Swaynwit, a blunt Countrey Gentleman.
Mr. Citwit, a Citizens Son that supposes himselfe a wit.
Mr. Daynty, a supposed Picture drawer, but a Pick-pocket.
Sir Raphael, an old Knight that talkes much and would be thought wise.
Sir Ferdinand, a Knight distracted for love of the Lady Strangelove.
Lady Strangelove, a humerous widow, that loved to be courted.

lg.l: WEe've cause to fear yours, or the Poets frowne
For of late day's (he know's not (how) y'are grown,
Deeply in love with a new strayne of wit
Which he condemns, at least disliketh it,
And solemnely protests you are to blame
If at his hands you doe expect the same;
Hee'l tread his usuall way, no gaudy Sceane
Shall give instructions, what his plot doth meane;
No handsome Love-toy shall your time beguile
Forcing your pitty to a sigh or smile.
But a slight piece of mirth, yet such were writ
By our great Masters of the Stage and Wit,
Whom you approv'd: let not your suffrage then
Condemne't in him, and prayse't in other men.
Troth Gentlemen let me advise yee, spare
To vex the Poet full of age and care,
How he might strive to please yee, and beguile
His humerous expectation with a smile,
As if you would be satisfy'd, although
His Comedy containes no antique show.
Yet you to him your favour may expresse
As well as unto those whose forwardnesse
Make's them your Creatures thought, who in a way
To purchace fame give money with their Play,
Yet you sometimes pay deare for't, since they write
Lesse for your pleasure than their own delight.
Which if our Poet fayle in, may he be
A Sceane of Mirth in their next Comedye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: YO' have given him then his answer?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Forc'd by you,
Heaven knowes with my much sorrow. Such a Lover
So in all points deserving of true worth,
And best indowments to make up a Man
That I shall never seeâ your pardon sir,
Though you pulld back, by violence, my hand,
In which my heart was freely given to him,
It is not in your power or strength of art
To beat a sigh back, or restraine a teare
Which I must offer to his memory.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Such stormes soone wast themselves in absent Lovers
When light of Reason, and good Counsell shall
Breake forth and shine upon 'em: and for your part
Daughter, I know it shall. And, presently,
I thus begin to dissipate your errors,
You love this Frederick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love knows I do.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You say he is deserving in all points.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My love emboldens me to tell you he is.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Charissa, take me with you. Is he not
Deficient in that onely absolute point
That must maintaine a Lady, an estate?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love weighes not that.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What can he shew you more
To take you with, then a wild head of hayre;
A very Limebush to catch Lady-birds?
A Tissue Doublet; and a Riband shop
Hung in his Hatbands, might set up a Pedler?
Can this maintaine a Lady?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: You but looke
Upon his outside sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I trust you have not
Bin over inwardly acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sir, he has Valour, Wit, and Honour, you well know
Hee's of a noble Family extracted.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: What's that a yeare? those parts may be acquir'd
In winning of a strumpet. But what Joincture
Can he propound to you? or, (in case he dyes,
Your Dowry being spent) what personall Estate
Ist like hee'l leave you, but his Powder glasse,
His Combe and Beard-brush, and perhaps a Trunkfull
Of Elegies, Raptures, Madrigalls and Sonnets?
No let him goe; discard him: and embrace
The hopes that I have for thee in the hopefull,
Exquisite Cavalier, Courtier and Souldier,
Scholler, (and what not!) brave Sir Ferdinando:
There's a Man rising in the favour Royall,
And may in thee Charissa, make me happy.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sir you have given me liberty of speech;
And may be pleas'd to let me tell you now,
You aime at your own fortune, not at mine.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I seeke no fortune, but for thy advancement:
All that I shall call mine must be thine owne.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I would be playner yet; beseeching you be not thought too lose in my obedience.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Speake freely Girle.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Your ayme has bin to raise
You state by Court-suits, begging as some call it,
And for that end you left your Countrey life,
And Lands too ever since my Mother dy'd,
Who while shee liv'd with best of womans judgement
Which held you from that course of selling faire
Possessions to enable you with money
To purchace wit at Court. You pardon me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: On, on.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: And for th' Exchange of a faire Mansion-house
Large fruitfull Fields, rich Medowes and sweet pastures
Well cropt with corne and stockd as well with Cattell,
A parke well stor'd with Deere too, and Fishponds in't,
And all this for a lodging in the Strand nowâ
But doe I not offend?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, no, on still.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Your own fed Beefes and Muttons, Fowle and Poultry
Loaded your long boords then; and you had then
Neighbours could boast your hospitality,
And poore, that for the remnants prayd for you,
Now all concludes upon a two-dishd table.
And whereas then you had a numerous Family
Of Servants and Attendants, out of which
For profit or for pleasure you could call
Your Bayliffe, Groom, your Falconer, or your Huntsman,
Now sir, a Varlet Coachman, and Footboy
Are all your Retinue; and for the Hounds
You kept, that made you sport and Musick, now
None but your project Beagles, that smell out
Where such a forfeiture is to be begg'd;
Where one would purchase a Reprieve, another
A Pardon or a lease of Life Rope-free
For ready money: Then where Goods or Lands
Are found of men that make away themselfes,
And so of fooles and madmen; All to set
Your trade of Begging up, and still you beg:
But your own want of favour holds you back
From reaching any profit by't, because
You beg by Mediators tongues, which you
Call Favorites, who reape the crop of all,
And leave you but the Gleanings; some small pittance
To keepe alive the itch of begging in youâ

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Shee speakes home and within me, to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Still wasting your own fortunes; till at last
You have no hopefull project left to thrive by
But to put me upon this suppos'd favorite
To beg for you when it is doubtfull yet
Whether hee'l take me with the Dowry, which
Mine Unkle left me, though you adde your projects.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: The noble Gallant loves thee, Girle, and holds
Thy Person and thy vertues Dowry enough,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: He is a wanton Lover, full of change,
And at this instant singularly devoted
Unto that humorous Lady, the young Widow.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The Lady Strangelove?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Shee is ambitious
To draw all mens affections to her service,
And then abuses all by scornes or slightings,
And this (they say) has made him almost mad.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: He mad! believe it not: his reason is
Married to him better then so. How now!
Ha' you seene the noble Knight from me?
How did he entertaine my Message? ha!
Why speakst thou not? what answer has he sent?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Hee's not Sir to be spoken with or seene
To any purpose, but by his Phisitians.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: So sodainly and dangerously sick,
Where are my hopes?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I cannot say how sick
He is; nor can himselfe give any account
Of his condition: for he is mad sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How I mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Starke staring mad; as mad
As you can thinke a Courtier must be
That is more mad then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: If this be true I sinke, what is suppos'd he cause?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That sir has puzzell'd all the Doctors
In weighing all his severall wild affections;
One findes he was ambitious of Court favour,
And guesses he was cross'd in some great suite;
Another takes him as he was a Souldier,
And losing cost and travaile in the warre
Must lose his wits for that. A third collects
He was a Poet that drunk too deepe of Helicon,
And turnd his braine in clyming of Parnassus:
A fourth considering that he was a Gamster
Long and much favourd, and uprais'd by fortune
To mountaynous heapes of Gold, conjectures, that
Some late unlucky hand or chance at play
Hath with his money swept his wit away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Fy, these can be no causes to remove,
To shake his settled judgement or his temper.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Then sir a fift and youngst head among
The learned men (what call you him for a Doctor?
Hay that affects gay clothes and Flanders Laces,
That trim effeminate Gentleman) he
Has known this noble patient to have beene
An extreame Amorist, desperatly devoted
Unto the service of some threescore Ladies,
And honord every one the most in costly presents,
Banquets and Verses; and thinks the disdaine
Of one or all of them has turnd his braine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I told you sir, the cause before; and nam'd
That humorous Lady for it, whom in heart
I can no lesse then thanke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Goe, get you up.
And stirre not from my Chamber on my blessing
Till my returne, nor admit any one
Unto a conference with you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I obey you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Some of your project searchers wait without sir
Loden it seemes with new intelligences.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They may come in: but as I feare they bring
Me little comfort, I am sure I shall
Afford them none. Now sirs, your businesse?

sp.speaker: 1. Pro.
sp.l: We wait upon your honour my good Lord
To crave the knowledge of what good successe
Your honor finds in our late suits my Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why honor? why my Lord?

sp.speaker: 2. Pro.
sp.p: We stile you now.

sp.speaker: 3. Pro.
sp.p: As all must doe hereafter.

sp.speaker: 1. Pro.
sp.l: Yes, and that
In a short space of time, the world holds no
Proportion else, nor shall it more be sayd
That money can buy Land; or great Estates
In Lands and Mannor-houses be call'd Lordships.

sp.p: Or wealth joynd with desert attaine to honor

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: So now the Game's a foot. They hunt in full cry

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: My Lord 'tis most apparant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How you torture me!

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Wee'l mak't appeare most plainly on our lives.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: And credits too.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Their Lives and credits, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: That in the space of one whole year our projects
Shall bring in fifty thousand pounds to us,
And hundred thousand to your selfe; and to
The Coffers Royall for full seaven years space
64 Thousand 783 l. 7 s. 9 d ob. q. per annum,
Tis here already cast. Which to make good
Wee'l venture Lives and Goods.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Our Wives and Children. Mend takes the scroll and peruses it.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: We can ingage no more.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: A wondrous strange ingagement
Your lives and goods; your wives & children gentlemen!
That's too deep set, and questions the Kings Mercy:
Me thinks it were enough, for non-performance
You would submit your bodies to perpetuall
Imprisonment at the Kings charge; and leave
Your wives and children to their severall Parishes
You are still faithlesse sir, in all projects.
But when you shall perceive the wealthy sonnes
Dayly brought in, and be, continually,
Troubled with the Receipts (if you may be trusted
That have so little faith) when you shall soyle
And gall your fingers ends with telling money,
Yet find the lickings of 'em sweet, you'l then
Sing other Notes.
Meane time entreat my Lord
To put you to some Tellers Clearke to teach you
Ambo-dexterity in telling money.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Do you hear sir? Can you give me two sixpences
For a shillingâ or any single money?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Cry mercy, you weare none in ready coine,
But all in Bullion lockt up in your brave-chests,
And there you have the treasure of the Indies;
Of deeper value, could it be digg'd out,
Then all the Hollanders have waited for
These 7 yeares out of the Spanish plate fleets.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But put mine eye out (now I dare you to't)
With any single peece of ready money.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: My Lord your man abuses us here strangely
With his old misbeliefe. But still we doubt not
Your honourable good opinion of us.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: You have pervs'd this weighty paper here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It weighes not all twelve graines.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: No more?
Nay the whole platforme of a stately City,
Or a designe to conquer a whole Nation,
But doe you note the grounds, the Rules and Reasons,
First for the easinesse of the severall grants.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Next for performance of our undertakings.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.l: And then the certainty o' th' propounded profits
Both to the King and us.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: Without all grievance unto the subject.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: That's no little marvaile.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: Take 'em into particulars my Lord,
First this for Perrukes. The Monopoly
Of making all the Perrukes male and female,
Through Court and Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: There's a capitall project.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.l: Note the necessity, that they be well made
Of no diseas'd or infectious stuffe, of dead or living,
No verminous or sluttish locks or combings,
But harmlesse and sound haire, of innocent,
And wholesome people.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: They must then reape none
From Gallowses, nor Hospitalls; from whence
They have had great supplies.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: You have in that
Said very well; For here's a Reformation
Of that abuse intended in these words
Innocent and wholsome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: How if a man or woman shall desire
To weare a friends hayre so departed; as
You his; or your wife yours; may't not be had?

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: Or if your friend or Mistris dye so, you
Procure the haire and bring it from the Gallows
To th' office, and it may be done accordingly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You have in that said very well Sir too.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: Now out of this provision, what an infinite
Profit will rise i' th' generall use of 'em,
And multiplicity that will be worne
By people of all sorts, degrees and ages:
The old to hide their naturall baldnesse, and
The young and middle-ag'd their artificiall
Or accidentall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: By the pox or so.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.l: They shall be brought into that reputation
That none shall be esteem'd so sound or wise
As publique wearers of them: which to effectuate
Tis requisite that you obtaine a Mandat
Unto all Courtiers, that would be thought wise
To weare false hayre: because clownes have been noted
To talke like fooles or mad men in their own.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No more of that.

sp.l: What say to this my Lord,
Touching new fashions of apparrell; sutes,
Hats, Boots, Swords, Belts, Ribands, &c.
For every wearer of his first o'th' fashion
To pay a groat to th' King; and every Tradesman
Two pence on every severall piece he sells
Of any such new fashion the first yeare?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: And what may this pride money amount unto
Per annum, can you guesse?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not meddle in it.
No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, nor your Perrukes neither.
What say to this my Lord of the Balconyes?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor that.
This then for sucking out of cornes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away with it.

sp.l: This then: that on the birth of every Girle
The Father pay a groat; to hearten men
To live soberly and get Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away.

sp.l: This makes amends for all then. A new project
For buylding a new Theatre or Play-house
Upon the Thames on Barges or flat boats
To helpe the watermen out of the losse
They've suffer'd by Sedans; under which project
The subject groanes, when for the ease of one
Two abler men must suffer; and not the price,
Or pride of Horse-flesh or Coach-hire abated.
This shall bring flouds of gaine to th' watermen
Of which they'l give a fourth of every fare
They shall boord at the floating Theatre,
Or set ashore from thence, the Poets and Actors
Halfe of their first yeares profits.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fy away.

sp.l: This is a weighty one: For massy summes
That may be freely given out of the City,
To have but this assurance, that hereafter
They may ingrosse the getting of their own
Children: by order tane that Cavaliers,
And Courtiers may no more invade,
Or mix with Tradesmens wives: whereby tis thought
So many City Prodigalls have been gotten;
Onely the thrifty countrey Gentlemen
To be excepted: for by them 'tis guest
So many Citizens grow landed men.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Were not they gotten by Projectors think you?
My Lord your servant jeeres us.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: To deale plainely
I doe allow't in himâ

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Heaven has heard my prayers.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And will heare him or any man oppose
All that is put to me by way of project
To put me by all further hopes in 'em:
For (with hearts griefe I speake it) he by whom
I onely hop'd to climbe (alas) is fallen.

sp.p: What out of favour?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, out of his Reason.
The noble Cavalier sir Ferdinando.

sp.l: That late stood candidate for the favour royall,
Is he now fallen besides himselfe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Even he.

sp.l: What have you then to doe my Lord
In lieu of all your service but beg him?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: His greater and his nearer friends at Court
Will prevent me.

sp.p: They shall not, never feare it.

sp.l: Come we will make quick worke of this.
My Lord you shall disburse but twenty pieces.
Among us three. 3. And we will instantly
Finde his estate. 1. And lay you down a way
So plaine that you shall say All's yours,
Before you stir a foot.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But when he has travell'd
Till he has tir'd himselfe, he shall returne,
And say All's lost, ist not so Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not part with any money sirs.

sp.l: Trust me you doe not well to put my Lord
Off o' his benefit, by disheartning him
In this small venture. Will you then be pleas'd
To give us but ten pieces.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.l: Five you shall my Lord,
And stand no longer thus in your own light.

sp.p: Or but a piece a Man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a denier.
A dinner then my Lord, but of one piece.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My answers cannot please you. Answer 'em you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I wonder how you having stretch'd your throats
With the loud sounds of thousands, hundred thousands
Can, after all, so faintly whisper forth
One piece; and that as much in vaine, as all
The massy summes: for all but brings you nothing,
It shewes you Gentlemen of resolute patience;
And would take thankfully I warrant you
An od halfe crowne amongst you: and what say you
To every man a kick on the condition?
What say you to one with tother?
This abuse
Shall lose your Master a hundred thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Goe coine your bullion braines into the money
And come againe. My master was
Your Lord even now, as he was Lord of Beggers.

sp.p: I hope to live to see him beg of us.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Out hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, hundred,
thousands, Millions, ten Millions, Millions upon Millions
Away, i'le stamp your buttocks into coyne else. Ex. Projectors.
The Devill ride that hindmost of 'em, for
A raw bon'd Jade: Sfoot he has lam'd my toes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am glad I am so rid of 'em, and now
As th'art my Servant and my loving Kinsemanâ

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: To follow you in all things but in Projects.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Looke to my House and Daughter, that she start not;
Nor any entrance be allowd to Fredrick
To re-intangle her in his Love. I know
Thy vertue and thy valour can make good
My trust impos'd in thee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: You need not feare sir
But, good sir, no more projects.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I have but one,
On which I'le set my rest. thoult say tis good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Except it be the begging of this Madman
It can be nothing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tis the very same:
By which I will advance my house and name. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: The Beggers best is that he feeles no shame:
Sprecious what meane you? Ha' you forgot so soone
Your Fathers strict command, and he scarce gone yet?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Alas hee'l then meet Fredrick and divert him,
I saw him at the window making this way.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: He gets no entrance to you. I must obay
A master though you can neglect a father.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Be not so cruell. Thou mayst live to love,
And need the pitty of a friend.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I pitty you,
And will do no more then you know how to aske
For your own good. I understand your cause
And can relieve you if you'l yeild to councell.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: You are my Kinsman; and have bin my friend,
Though you observe my father who, I feare,
Has not a fathers love towards me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: His love is great and certaine,
And all his travell is for your advancement:
But he goes blindfold on unprosperous wayes
Led by credulity. Projects! pox o' projects
The patron of his projects is (it seemes)
Pepper'd with madnesse. Tis but Justice on him,
And now i'le give you a secret if you'l promise
To be ruld by me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: You shall rule me cosen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This Ferdinand, your fathers great Court-godling
Nere sought you for a wife; but to have whor'd you:
(That is the English on't) and to appeare
A right great man in th'act, he would ha' made
By hopes and promises your credulous Father
The instrument of your prostitution:
Which to effect, (though still he undertook
His hopefull projects) cunning Lawyer-like
He crost or lost him still in all, on purpose
That poverty at length might urge him to
Give you to his dispose.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This was my feare.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Away: some body comes.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tis Fredrick. I must see him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You'l never see him more then. Go to your chamber. A little patience and he shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So dos a heart consume in lingring fire,
When cooling hopes are cast on hot desire. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Poore heart I pitty her, and will labour for her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: O Gabriel! I am happy in finding thee,
Thy master absent, whom I saw, in hast
Now passing towards the Court. Where's my Charissa?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You may not see her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May not see her sir?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: May not! nay must not: shall not see her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Y'are very plaine with me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Her owne command
Warrants me speake it sir.

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.p: A villaine speakes it. Draw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I have a sword speakes other language for me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Can she whose thoughts are truth, and written here,
Here in this breast, giving me ample welcome,
Give thee a countermand to bar me from it?
Wouldst thou make her a double hearted monster?
Or like another woman?
Repent thee of thy trespasse yet and live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sir, if you thinke to fight, talke not too much;
Or, if you needs must talke, then heare as well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What wouldst thou say?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sir, I have more to say
Then fits this place, since you are apt to quarrell;
And this no ground to bustle on: nor indeed
Where I dare for my honesty and trust
Allow you longer stay. If therefore you
Will walke, I'le wait upon you; and direct you
In a more ready way to finde Charissa.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is shee not here i' th' house?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O sir, a man
May come within his arme-reach of his money
In the Exchequer: but he must walke about
To finde due order e're he draw it out.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: The fellow's honest, valiant, and discreet,
Full man, in whom those three additions meet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Sir, dare you trust me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Yes I dare; and why?
Because if thou dar'st fight, thou dar'st not lie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: HEre in this gallery Gentlemen you may, at your pleasure,
Untill my Lady comes, walk or sit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Or lie down if you please.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: If you so, wrong not my Ladies Couch with your Spurres I pray: take heed you leave not a Rowell there.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: If one should, your Lady has no Lord to call her honour to question, whose Knight-hood it belong'd unto.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You have a good countrey wit sir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My name is Swayne-wit; and for all you twit me with the Countrey, I am a Gentleman tho'.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I honour you the more sir, for I am a Countrey Maide my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Thou art a baggage, and a bold one, I am deceiv'd else.
I would be further acquainted with you tho'. Kisse long.
Have you done now? You will have time enough for
Further and better acquaintance.
sp.p: Thou art a Jackanapes of the basest tricks that ever I saw, for a halfe-penny. Shee's your choyce, is shee? Could not you let be tho'? I ha' bin acquainted with thee but two dayes, and forgi' me for swearing, I ha' found thee beating ripe a skore o' times at least. Take heede I begin not now, and handsell your Ladies house, that is so much talkt on, and your Gentlewomans presence here with a fist about your eares.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Not for a thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: That's a great deale of money. I could find i'my heart to do't tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Slife we are all undone then.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: He sets my teeth on edge to looke upon him: He lookes so like a wilding crab, good neither for drink nor sauce.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Why would you presse him then?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou hast a verjuice wit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: For my poore sake forbeare sir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Let him stand further then, and looke o' toe side.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well sir, this is no cause nor place to fight in, whenâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What sayes he?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nothing, you heare he whistles tother way.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tother way, what backwards?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: What new guest ha' you brought here Mr. Court-wit, for my Lady to laugh at?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: One for that purpose Phil, you ha' spoke the man, But what company has my Patronesse, that shee is yet busy.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that! If shee be long busy I will not stay, and shee were ten great Ladies, or one as big as twenty, for all shee is your Patronesse, must we wait out of our wits, because Chalivere ran mad for her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Ha' you heard o' that sir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My Cozen Court-wit's question was who's with her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O sweet Mr. Court-wit, when will you bring the fine civill Gentleman, that maintaines himselfe so gallantly by picture drawing?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a new businesse! Fare yee well, pray tell your Lady I came not from Pensans to grow here.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nay sweet sir stay, there is sir with my Lady none but the grave and witty talking Knight. Some call him the metrapolitane wit of Court; he that loves Ladyes society so much, and yet has vow'd virginity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: As much as in man lies Phil; Hee is a perpetuall vowd batchellor indeed, and as constant to his vow as to his fashion in apparrell, which is ever the same, sir Raphael Winter-plum.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That old witherd piece. I know him.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wilt beare up again.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He has lick'd up a living with his tongue; makes all great tables his own; and eats for his talke. He may be conversant with women: for (they say) he guelt himselfe
beyond Sea for spight one did him; and now preaches chastity to Ladies, and love to their husbands. Hee's a Lay-gospeller among the married sort, and an especiall pedant to the youth o' Court.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fy, thou speakst too much.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There's another humor I could beat thee for with all my heart, thou wilt speake outragiously of all men behinde their backs, and darst not answer Baâ to the face of a sheep, O I could pommell thee.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This is not yet a cause to fight for, whenâ

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: But will not that fine Gentleman Mr. Dainty come, Mr. Court-wit?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I expect him presently.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I'le see if their conference be ended, or breake it if I can, and hasten my Lady to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: This wench has a dainty wit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee may, living with the prime Lady-wit in towne.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But what Dainty is that shee talkes on so affectionately?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Troth a Gentleman that lives at a good rate; very civill in conversation, keepes good company; yet none of his acquaintance that I am acquainted with knowes his beginning, or his present meanes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I know no more but by his port, and fashion, you saw him with me last night.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for swearing, Ist he?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He was at the Play with us too, doe you not remember that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, that I was at the Play, by sure token and a sad one.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le shew you somewhat of him. A Gentleman borne did you aske?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Now he beares up againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hee cannot be a Gentleman by birth or place. A fine-handed, and a fine headed fellow he is; and pretends great skill and practice too in Picture-drawing, Watch-making, and such like finger workes; which he sayes he uses as a Gentlemans exercise, not as a trade to live upon; when either he does live on't; or else hee has some more secret way, as perhaps pimping or pursing for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There he is again! Art thou bound in conscience to wrong all men in their absence, till I beate thee into better manners?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Hold hold, I prithee hold.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yet still the cause is insufficient, whenâ

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Here comes the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Is hee come? Noble Mr. Daintyâ The welcomst in the World. I protest I suffer'd by your absence.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You do me too much honour Mr. Cit-wit.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Oh sir, your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Ha, ha. Forgi' me for swearing, what a Spaniell's this?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are well found, I was a little stayd by the way upon receipt of monies. Ha' you seene the Lady yet?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee's yet a little busy. We shall all instantly take the opportunity together.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: But Gentlemen; you that have better knowledge of this Lady informe if you please, why are we summond hither?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thou speakst as if thou hadst guilt upon thee; fear nothing man.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
I that's the thing that I would understand too. And why me of any man? They say indeed shee is a humorous Lady, and loves to busy her selfe. But what are we to her? are there not greater men, and Lords enough
for her to foole away the time with, but we must dance attendance on her humors?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I protest Mr. Swayn-wit, I admire your ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You will be medling still.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Tis to your question sir, which I will answer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I there's another of your cockscombly tricks, to answer any question, that's ask'd another man, out with tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This Lady sir, this humorous wity Lady is a wit-sponge, that suckes up wit from some, and holds as her own, untill shee squeeze it out on others. Shee will make use of ours, or any courser wits; and search 'em out to sift 'em. Shee will collect from market-folkes; and hold conferences with the poore Trades-people that cry their wares about the streets, Shee will rake wit out of a dunghill Ragwoman.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: So there he is againe! darest thou abuse a noble Lady, in her owne house too? I dare not now but beat thee.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare good cosen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Still, still, the cause is naught, whenâ

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Ods so the Ladies comming I think.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lady cannot yet be rid of the tedious talking Knight. But shee will cast him presently. He is now following her into this roome, pray passe into the next; my Ladies Musick roome. There you shall find a collation of good Tobacco and Sack and one to attend you, you know the fashions of the House Mr. Court-wit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come away Gentlemen. Exit Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I could even love and looke upon that sweete Mr. Dainty a whole houre methinks.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Goe your wayes down Mayd, and if any aske for Sir Raphael here, say that I hope hee will ha' done anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You would be rid of me: but pardon me Madam, I must hold your glasse to you.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: That's a poore Chamber-mayds office; and ill becomes your gravity Sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'le open then the booke to you of your errors.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now you speake scholler-like, and your selfe: But have we spent all this while in by, and idle talke, and have that volume to be open'd yet? Pray read mee for the first Lesson for this Mornings Exercise, and my Edification, the last Chapter of my book of errors as you call it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are a mocker of instruction, and good counsell.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Begins it so? whom is that spoken to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I speak to onely you; to conjure (if I can) that spirit of scorne out of you; which you have taken in, and long affected for a humor, your singular own humor, till it is grown so familiar, so inherent in you, that you have wonne the title of the humorous Lady by't; and drawn a scorne upon your selfe.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Why then all's paid, and wellcome good Sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am not gone so; nor is all so payd:
For there's a greater reckoning yet of Raylings,
Reviling, Curses by the many that
Y'have scornd and slighted, shot at you in hot vollies.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: They hit me not. I am sure I do not feele 'em.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: You may in time be sensible of their suffrings,
Whom you have violently, and willfully abus'd
With scorne and pride; if you call to mind
The cause, bred meerly out of humour; cause you would have it so.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You come too neare mee sir, cause I would have it so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Can it be otherwise? Has it not ever bin
Your practise, since your time of widow-hood
To catch all mens affections? Tis indeed
An honour to a Lady to have many suitors;
But to lay bait for 'em only to delude 'emâ
Is impiously dishonorable.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Have I done so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, and have gloried in it for your humour
To lead men into brakes with foolish fire.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: If they will follow it, I cannot helpe it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You might though have prevented the mishaps
Of many, by a faire and free resistance
In the beginnings of their suits of Courtships,
And not to set your selfe at gaze to draw them on,
And then allure them with assured hopes
Of love and favour till you have wound their follies
Into the reach of your disdaine; and then
To torture 'em, or having ta'ne 'em captives
To slave and sell 'em to the worlds derision.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: O sir Raphaelâ

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Shee feeles compunction!
I will pursue it to the quick.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: On good Sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Consider then good Madam, since I know,
And your own conscience knowes, that you have made
A secret vow from your late husbands death
Never to marry, how better and more glorious
It would be for your honor to declare
Your constant purpose to a single life,
Then to fall into the transgression
Of robbing men so of their wits and reason,
And all by willfull humor; as this late
Unhappy accident of madnesse in
The hopefull Knight Sir Ferdinando cryes
Lowdly to your disgrace, and the worlds sorrow.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Halfe the worlds sorrow is mine own
For that sad accident, I would I coold redeem't
With halfe my health or life. But let me tell you
(Now you have justly chidden me) that you
Have a fault too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What ist in your construction?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: As I conceal'd my vow of single living,
And gave men leave to court me, by which meanes
I won them into hopes, and robd their wits,
You in declaring to the Court and City
Your vow of chastity and single life,
Yet dayly, nightly, howerly frequenting
The company of Ladies, with your sweet,
No lesse then grave discourse and conversation
Have rob'd (nay I may say deflowr'd) more Ladies
Of chast and honorable thoughts, then all
The cavalry of Court.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who I Madam!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Even you sir Raphael (if unchast desires
Must be held sinfull) I know some of them,
And one (I feare) too well, that have bin subject
Unto the breach of any vow for you,
Yet you to vow a single and chast life;
And publish your intent!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Tis with intent,
And a religious purpose to decline,
And divert womans fond affections from me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: O, but forbidden things are womens longings!
You have read, you have read (sir Raphael) you have read. Falls on her Couch.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And travell'd too: yet never could discover
Such an example.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray sit down by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good thoughts possesse you Madam. I must hence.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le not be tedious to you. One word I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Vertue, be thou my armor. Briefly then
Let me intreat you Madam:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Pray refuse not
To sit downe by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sanctity protect me. Sit.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, you are famous, and cry'd up by all
For your great wisdome, Morall and Divine:
You are the Ipse dixit of the Court
As I have heard you stil'd by men of learning,
The Court Philosopherâ

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam to the point.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What is our strength, and what is not our frailty?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Where is shee wandering now? Bee playner Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Doe not my blushes (which I hope you pardon)
Deliver you a message from my heart?
Which I want words to utter? O these vowes!
These rash and ill-made vowes! dos not your judgement
Read something on this face? pray look upon me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am no good interpreter of looks.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I dare not speake, till you have first remov'd
A weighty scruple, which doth much perplexe me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You must first speake it Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whether these vowes,
(I meane your own, and mine, for single life)
May safely be dispens'd with or absolv'd,
And we become a lawfull paire in Marriage?
Pray sir resolve and blesse me in a Match.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam I'le pray for you. Starts up.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You will first kill me
With your disdaine, and then you'l pray for me!
Is that your Charity?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I dare not heare you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Leave me not so.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who waits upon my Lady here? Exit.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I had no other way to shift him, would he would make
An errand now to Rome to quit my scruple;
And rid the Court of an officious foole:
Women some times have sent wise men to schoole.
Is the Knight gone?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And blessing of himselfe,
As witch-craft were i'th' house.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But where's my favorite Court-wit, has he brought his countrey Kinsman and the rest?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: They are all in your wit-office Madam (as you call the Roome)
Passing the time among the Pipes and Bottles,
And singing catches. Here you may heare 'em Madam. A catch.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Marry, this takes past all sir Raphaels Lectures,
Goe call 'em downe. Exit Phi.
This Madam troubles me, 'would he were right agen;
Or I quit of the scandall.
O Gentlemen! y'are welcome,
And chiefly you that are the onely stranger,
I ha' been so troubled with an overtalking sir, that he
Has wound me into melanchollyâ

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I wish you mirth Madam. I come not as one o' you fooles to make you any thoughâ Offer to go away.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Be not so briefe with mee, let mee intreat you though.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for swearing doe you mock me tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Mistake me not sweet sirâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
Sweet with a mischiefe! How sweet am I? I come
not as a suitor to your great Ladyship, I am a Gentleman of two hundred a yeare tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Not as a suitor to me sir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: No you are too great for me. Nor to your Mopsey without, though shee be snout-faire, and has some wit shee's too little for me, I understand degree and quality, respect and difference; and am scholler enough to know my unde and my quare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ga' me his true character. You are a compleat Gentleman sir (if I mistake not) the Kinsman of my favorite here, who has given me an ample relation of your worth and vertue.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Yes, Patronesse, 'tis he, who though not throughly vers'd, or conversant i'th' Court or City garbe, he understands both Men and Manners.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Prattle for your selfe sir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But to the businesse Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that I would faine know if it be any.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You have heard I doubt not of a disastrous blot lately cast upon my fame, out of my owne freenesse.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Concerning the Mad courtier Madam, when 'tis as likely, that his Taylor made him mad as you, for not hitting the fashion right in his last rich suit. But tis most like he fell from a reasonable man, by over-studying himselfe what Lord he should be at the next creation, whether of Gleek, or Cribbidge; In and in, or Hazard.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Hearke how this shotten headed Cocks-combe prates! And how he, that can indure beating, dares speak any thing, or abuse all men! canst not give the Lady leave to speake tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
Since there is an aspersion layd upon my freenesse in giving entertainment unto persons of great and noble quality, the world deeming it to be done by me meerly
for ostentation, to cry my own humor up, by drawing them into Love-knots, and then to slight or scorne them: My resolution is from henceforth, to exclude those great resorts, and friendly and freely be merry within our selfes. I have foure thousand a yeare to spend; and will be huswife good enough to keepe in compasse. I will not entertaine a servant, friend or guest above your rank or fortunesâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Whyâ (forgi'me for swearing) what do you think of us?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I thinke you Gentlemen of worth and quality: and therefore welcome. I thinke you able to maintaine your selfes midle-sis'd Gent.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am Midlesex indeed; borne i' th' City.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Give the Lady leave to speake tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'le give accesse to none, that the censorious world shall dare to judge a suitor to me,
Or to finde favour further then meat and wine.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, faith a little money to; and make's your Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray give the Lady leave to speak though. whew

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Mauger the greatnesse of my former visitants
I give you my election for the chiefes
Of my familier society.
I may perhaps call in, (at least admit)
People of meaner garbe, without (I hope
Your grudge or envy. But they shall be men
Of Science, Art, and Action.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Of action Madam? who do you meane? the Players?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Why not? I love their quality and them, and mean to have the use of some of 'em shortly: Besides Musitians (Poets in the first place) and Painters: In which last mention'd art I heare you are excellent, though all this while so silent.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I boast no skill or practise Madam: but I have drawne some pieces that have been worth my paines in my Rewards.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I must commend their ingenuity for whom you tooke those paines. But (where I left) I must make use of wits, of arts, and actions.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here in your house Madam, I would be glad to see the Actors but I saw 'em at their own too lately: for I lost my purse there, no matter let it go. There was 15. pound in't tho!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sprecious! How now! my Fob has been fubd to day of six pieces, and a dozen shillings at least. Nothing but a bowd groat left as I hope for my Grannums blessing.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sure you have been in some ill company.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pox of ill company I say. My watch is gone out of my Pocket too o'th right side.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You rose o' the wrong side to day it seemes, were you in no crowd or quarrell?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I never was in any quarrell i'my life. I alwayes run from 'em.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I dare sweare thou dost.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I onely stood to day at the Coranto-shop to read the last great news; and I was hoop'd in I remember by some that seem'd to wonder as much as I.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Then certainly there was a cut-purse amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le go to honest Moll about it presently.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But first stay and heare my Lady tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I Madam you were speaking of the use you would make of Poet, Painter, Musick, Actor and the like.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
True favorite for a Masque that I intend to have shortly, you shall performe the poeticall part, your
servant Citwit the Musicall. And by your skill and directions the Painters office for the scenes. Dancers and speakers I have in store.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I must be something too tho', must I not Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Marry and thanke you too sir.
Now your Newes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Mendicant desires to see you Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You should have told him I would not be seene by him.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I told him you were busy. But hee sayes hee is to speake with you upon a weighty businesse from the Court.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Tis the Court-begger. You know him favorite.
Goe not away, I'le bring him in amongst you,
And (as you love me) put some ridiculous projects to him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What's that sir Andrew Mendicant? doe you know him well?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Thou askest still a question like a guilty person, with a look resembling fear upon thy face.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: My countenance is too blame then; not my conscience.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le tell you what he is.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Still answering others questions?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He is a Knight that hanckers about the Court, ambitious to make himselfe a Lord by begging. His braine is all Projects, and his soule nothing but Court-suits. He has begun more knavish suits at Court, then ever the Kings Taylor honestly finish'd, but never thriv'd by any: so that now hee's almost fallen from a Pallace Begger to a spittle one. His businesse to my Lady now can be nothing but to borrow money to buy a paire of wheeles
to set some Project a going to Court for a Monopoly.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wert in hast eene now to looke after the money; but and thy Life lay on't thou must stay to abuse a man behinde his back, who is a noble Gentleman thou knowst, and I have heard, yet (speake in thy conscience) wouldst thou not be beaten now?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare, they come.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, since it is requested by those great ones
Whose power cannot command me in this case
(For tis my charity and not my duty)
I am content that the mad Ferdinand
Shall sojourne in my house for his recovery.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tis thought you were the ground-work of his frensy
The Doctors therefore mov'd their honours to it
For that your frequent presence may be helpfull
Towards his care.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: He shall have it then
Towards the expiation of the crime
They charge me with. But in case sir Andrew
He should be cur'd by this meanes, I should then
Crosse you in fortune and your future hopes
Of his estate; which you have beg'd you say
If he recover not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I must leave that to fortune Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Will you be pleas'd sir to take notice of
These Gentlemen my friends. They may be usefull Salute
For they have all projective braines I tell you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray of what nature are your Projects Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sir my affection leanes much to Poetry, especialy the Drammatick.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Writing of strange Playes?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I am glad I speake sir, to your understanding.
And my project is that no Playes may be admitted to the Stage, but of their making who Professe or indeavour to live by the quality: That no Courtiers, Divines, Students at Law, Lawyers-clearks, Tradesmen or Prentises be allow'd to write 'em, nor the Works of any lay-Poet whatsoever to be receav'd to the Stage, though freely given unto the Actors, nay though any such Poet should give a summe of money with his Play, as with an Apprentice, unlesse the Author doe also become bound that it shall doe true and faithfull service for a whole Terme.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Here's a trim businesse towards, and as idle as the Players going to Law with their Poets.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I have another sir, to procure a Patent for my selfe to have the onely priviledge to give instructions to all the actors in the City, (especially the younger sort) the better to enable them to speake their parts emphatically and to the life.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You were best take heede in time then that you well preserve your own voyce, for feare you doe a spoyle among 'em in teaching 'em to utter in unsavory tunes. Doe I come hither to be mock'd?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Will you heare mine though? I am a Countrey Gentleman, young, healthfull and lusty. I heare complaints of barrennesse in the City; and of men that cannot get their wives with child; Get me but a Patent for't I'le undertake by my selfe and deputies (provided that the woman be sound and handsome) to make them multiply, and upon reasonable conditions: we will deale with the rich for money, and the poore for charity.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is foolisher then tother. Doe you abuse me Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Is that a wise man's question? you cannot tell th'o.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We have our projects too Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I would have yours first, you see me a civill and substantiall Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: In more private if you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I like well his reservednesse.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir I am a Picture-drawer Limner, or Painter (if you please) and would gladly purchase authority, by my selfe and deputies, for the painting of all the Kings, and Quenes-head signes for Tavernes, Innes, Ale houses, and all Houses and Shops of Trade throughout the Kingdome upon this ground that they draw and hang up their royall Images for signes in so hideous manner that men blesse themselves to see't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I marry this hangs upon some ground. But are you an exquisite workeman in that art sir?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I am an Artist in that mistery sir, and have drawn some of his Majesties Pictures (by coppy onely but) so to the life, that Gentlemen have kneel'd to 'em for suites, and knight-hoods.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Indeed sir!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yes sir, and great Lords I have pictur'd so powerfully, their own followers sodainly rushing into the room have started back and solemnly stood bare to 'em as they hung o'the walls.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ist possible!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I drew a sterne Judge, and a civill Lawyer so to the life, that after their corps were in the Grave, a man durst not looke upon their pictures without a bribe, or double fee in's hand.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I do admire you!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I ha' drawn Ladies too, with that alluring beauty, that men have loy'd their dead pictures, for their painted lookes, more then their living persons for all their vertues.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou boy! introth you abuse me most merrily Gentlemen. Goe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: An excellent fellow: I like him for that fancy more then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray heare my project too sir?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Yes good sir Andrew, you shall not part so abruptly.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Mine is a good common wealths businesse, against the common Plague, that raignes i' th' City of Pick-pockets, and Cut-purses. I my selfe ha' bin robb'd to day, and am going to a good member that deales in private for the recoveries of such goods: One that shall undertake if you'l but get a Patent, for a Cutpurse-hall, or Office, to helpe all men to their owne againe, allowing but the Tithes of their Losses, and freeing the offending parties.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fie, fie. Here's tithing indeed.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Provided that notice be brought to the Office within foure and twenty houres after any such losse.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Enough, enough.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Wee may by the same course secure the Counties too, and make the hangman hang himselfe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let every man be wise enough to looke to his purse, and there will be no Cut-purses, nor need of your patent.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: As wise a man as you may lose his purse tho', as I ha' done my selfe in a crow'd.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He puts me in mind of a crowd I was in once to day of company I lik'd notâ haâ. For heaven 'tis gone: And I dare not discover it for being laught at.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: It seemes none of your Projects will passe with you sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come sir, they are but (as you said) merry with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Be you merry with them good Madam, you know the serious worke I came about. In which
I sodainly shall presume to give you a re-visite.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray do sir Andrew, bring your Mad-man. My garden Lodgings shall be his bedlem. Come gentlemen tis Dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: We are your waiters Madam. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: THese are the Lodgings, that my Lady appointed
For your distracted patient.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Like you 'em Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Exceeding well. Excuse me Gentlewoman
That now intreat your absence.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Willingly. I am not taken with the sight you bring
For I see mad-folkes enough every day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here set him downe. Unbind him, and unblind him. Ferdinand brought in a chaire bound and hooded, &c.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Am I then taken prisoner in the North?
Wounded, disarm'd and bound? I shall be ransom'd
To which of your rebelliously usurp'd
Castles ha' you brought me? you sir Presbiter,
That better can pugnare then orare,
And so abjure all duty and allegianceâ

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Hee takes you for a Northerne Pastor Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No matter what, let him run out his fancy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You were best to use me well; and like a souldier
Order will else be tane (though you know none.)

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You shall have all best usage sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And use my horse well too, and let my horse and armor
Be decently preserv'd and seene forth-comming
At my redemption.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: With all best care sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For I shall soone be sent for, or fetch'd off
With ruine of your countrey 'bout your eares.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You shall have all content the countrey yeilds sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I shall have Oat-bread, Ale, and Bag-pipes, shall I?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you'l be merry sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Merry! why not? come let's ha' cards; and you and I to cribbidge
For an od hundred pound, I meane not Scotch,
But sterling English pieces, where's your money?
All gone in Ammunition, and charge Military.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'le finde you money enough.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O here's a third man, let's then to Gleeke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Crown Gleeke sir, if you please.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Crown Gleeke! no more?
You seeme to be a thrifty Covenanter
To play but at crowne Gleeke, whole piece Gleeke or nothing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: High as you please sir, wee'l find money enough,
And pay us but our buyings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sir, you must bare mee Aces. You will play Tib and Tom.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All i' the Cards sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Away with cards. Bring dice, set all at hazard,
And though I lose all, I have yet a project
That at the end o'th' war, and the great sitting
Shall fetch all in agen. But O my Muse!
How dare I so neglect thy inspirations?
Give me Pen, Inke and Paper.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All's ready.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now will I write, nor will I emulate
Ovids smoth vaine, or Petraks buskind stile.
Nor Laura, nor Corinna did deserve
To have their prayers written in such Verse
As i'le bestow on her that I adore.
Listen to me you blest Intelligences,
And, Phebus, stay thy course to heare me sing
Her prayses, for whose love th' inamor'd Gods
Would leave their proper seates, and in stolne shapes,
Converse with mortalls, your soule-ravishing spheres
Send forth your sweetest harmony whilst I singâ
But O shee is disdainfull; and her scorne
Hath blotted all the glory of her praise,
Away, away with all.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now sir, doe you observe the roote of his Disease?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I guesse at it, know you the remedy?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Disease! what's that? who is diseas'd? who wants a Remedy?
Are you sir a Phisitian?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This Gentleman is, and brings you remedy, be you patient.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O you will move him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are a brace of Quacks,
That tie your knowledge unto dayes and houres
Mark'd out for good or ill i' th' Almanack.
Your best Receipts are candy for a cold;
And Carduus Benedictus for an ague,
Could you give life as Aesculapius
Did to unjustly slaine Hippolitus,
You could prescribe no remedy for me.
Goe study Gallen, and Hippocrates,
And when your rare simplicities have found
Simples to cure the Lunacy of Love,
Compose a potion, and administer't
Unto the Family at Amsterdam.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I'le Phisick you to morrow and allay
The heate of this strong fit, or Leach it out.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have venter'd to this house againe, assur'd
That now the humerous Lady is from home
Forgetting not her Love-trick put upon me
Which she already boasts to my disgrace
For which I may requite her Ladyship,
How dos your patient? a sleepe! That's well.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No hee's but silent sir, and it is well
That he is so, so long.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: The Lords in honorable regard unto
His health directed me to visite him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Do you not know me sir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You are (I tak't) the Ghost of Dionisius
The great tirannicall Court-schole-master.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Your Friends at Court commend them to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What hither, unto hell? Extend their loves
So far, to finde me out? Pray let 'em know
That here's a trobled world in want of Statesmen.
But tell the youthes and beauties there, they never
Shall finde a happier opportunity
To raise a new Plantation. They'l drive all
Before 'em here. For pride is at a stand;
Fashions are all worne out, and no invention
For new here to be found: all beauty's lost;
Nor have the greatest Ladies here the act
To make so much as their poore Chambermayds:
Let 'em come downe, as many of the Gallants
As are made weary of their Wives or Mistresses;
And, of those Wives and Mistresses, as many
As can their husbands, or their servants spare:
And what a yeare of Holy-dayes, a Jubile
Shall we have in hell then? Ha' old Lad!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What a wilde fancie's this!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Crosse it not good sir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pray give mee leave to touch it though, a little.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But above all, finde out the Lady Strangelove
That humorous Madam, and tell her from me,
The many Lovers shee has sent before her
Into these shades (where we can find no torments
Like those that shee inflicted) have prevail'd
With the great Queene Proserpina, that shee
Shall be in place next to her royall person.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: The Lady Strangelove! you are in her house sir,
Where doe you thinke you are? or who you are?
Pray call your selfe to mind sir, are not you
The noble Cavalier and hopefull Courtier
The most accomplish'd Knight sir Ferdinando?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Forbeare sir, you will move him strongly else.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have authority for what I do sir,
Can you forget your selfe sir, or neglect
The bounteous fortunes, that the Court and Kingdome
Have in store for you, both for past Atchievments,
And for the large endowments of court-vertue
Are found still growing in you, studied and practis'd
So to the life, as if you were built up
Vertues own Mansion, on her foure firme pillars?â

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I hope he cannot flatter him into's wits
When 'tis the way to foole men out of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: The Wisdome, Justice, Magnanimity,
And temperance of court you are exactly
Fram'd and compos'd of, and indued with all
The excelencies that may adorne a man
By Nature, Fortune, Art and Industry!
And all this glorious light to be eclips'd;
And such Divine perfections seeme to sleepe?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Pray sir your eare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, most attentively.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What do you thinke of Salsbury steeple sir,
For a fit hunting speare t' incounter with
The whore of Babilion? might I not firke her thinke you?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Your Doctrine dos not edify sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is Oratour Demostines growne dumbe
O'th' sodaine? what! no answer? give me a Knife
He is but tongue-tied.

sp.speaker: Ra:
sp.p: Guard me Divinity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I told you what you would doe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Patience good sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Patience in tortures?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Helpe here sodainly!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do you sally forth in troupes? Have I no troupe?
Give me my horse and armes, and come a hundred.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Wee'l arme and horse you, since y'are so unruly,
Away with him into his Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O doe you make me then your Knight o' th' shire A tun o' Wine for that. Shoulder your Knight, advance your Knight, beare him out. Manent Men.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A Ferdinand, a Ferdinand, &c.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This now to me is Musick, Golden-chimes
That rings all in with an assur'd advantage,
How now Sir Raphael! Frighted?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In all my disputations all my travailes,
And all conspiracies that have bin had
Aagainst me, never met I an incounter
By man, or spirit that I feard so much,
Yet here's another fury.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: By what oppression or tiranny (for Law
I'm sure could never do't) is my house here
Confiscated or usurp'd, and I become your slave?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Your slave, lay your commands on mee, what drudgery doe you appoint me to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Shee's mad too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Did not your Ladyship give way?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: To make my house a hell?
The noyse of Bedlem is soft Musick to 't.
Could your Projectorship find no house else
To make a mad-man madder in but mine?
And me as mad as he too with the trouble.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I was no principle in't good Madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Was it your plot then sir Philosophaster,
That so you might under pretext of reading
Philosophy to him, to cure his madnesse
Make your adresse to me to prosequte
Your Love-suite when I thought I had answer'd you,
But if you must proceede, o'recome me if you can,
Yet let me warne you to take heede withall
You pull not a disease unto you, that may
By your ungovern'd hast post into
Your grave: for I shall prove a torment to you,
Though you'l take no denyall, take yet a warning.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I take it to forsake your house; and never
More to resort where madnesse raignes. Did I
Make love to you?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pardon mee vertuous sir, it is my love to you that tortures mee into this wild distraction. O sit Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Now vertue guide me. I will shun this place
More then I would the Spanish Inquisition.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I shall in time be rid of all such Guests,
And have the liberty of mine owne house
With mine own company, and to mine own ends
Where are you Phil? I were but dead if I had not this wench to foole withall sometimes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I must be a little serious with you, shut the dore.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Now am I call'd into correction,
When shee is vext and wants the company
Shee likes, then come I into question,
'Tis common among Ladies with their women.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why that down looke, as if you meant to fetch
An answer, or excuse out of your Apron-strings
Before you are charged or question'd? what new faule
Has past of late?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Doe you read any Madam
Upon my face or lookes? I never was in love
Much with my face, nor ever hated it. But if I thought
It had upon't, or in it, any trespasse
Against your Ladyship (my heart being cleare)
These Nayles should claw it out. Teare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Nay be not passionate Phil. I know you cannot
Forget the care I have had of you; nor should you
Distrust me in the promises I have made you,
Bearing your selfe according to your covenant Phil,
Of which one Article is to laugh with me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Go, you are such a Lady, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now thou comst to me wench: hadst forgot?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You said you would be serious.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Dost not thou know my seriousnesse is to laugh in private,
And that thou art bound to stir that humour in me?
There's but two things more condition'd in thy service;
To do what I bid thee, and tell me the truth
In all things that I aske thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I Madam, you had never known that same else.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Of the clap thou hadst i'the Countrey e're I took thee,
But hast thou faithfully kept thine own e're since?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes most severely Madam on your promiseâ

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Well we will have a husband then to solder up the old crack,
I have already made my choyce for you:
Your sweete-heart Cit-wit makes most suite to you,
And has a good Estate, and wit enough
Too for a husband, and a handsome person.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I finde no fault in all that. But he is
So base a coward, that he may be soone
Beaten out of his wit and money.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if he should prove valiant!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: If he were valiant now I could say something,
But to wait for growing to't were such a losse of time.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What say to Swayn-wit?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hee's the others extreame. I might feare him but never love him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What think you of my speciall favorite Mr. Court-wit?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: As of a Courtier Madam, that has tasted
So much of all waters, that when he has a fountaine of his owne
Hee'l be too jealous of it.
And feard that every man will drink of's cup
When perhaps none dares touch it, were I it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What say to Dainty then the curious Limner?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I am bound from lying. Madam hee's the man.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well i'le take thy cause in hand wench: But yet we are not merry. I am inclin'd most jovially to mirth me thinks. Pray Jove some good be towards. Laugh or i'le pinch you, till you doe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha. O the picture drawer! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I, come, the Picture drawer.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
O, I love drawing and painting, as no Lady better,
who for the most part are of their occupation that professe it. And shall I tell all Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: By all meanes Phil.â now shee's enter'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hope I am handsome enough too. For I have heard that Limners or Picture-drawers, doe covet to have the fairest and best featur'd wives, (or if not wives, Mistresses) that they can possibly purchace, to draw naked Pictures by, as of Diana, Venus, Andromeda, Leda, or the like, either vertuous or lascivious; whom they make to sit or stand naked in all the severall postures, and to lie as many wayes to helpe their art in drawing, who knowes how I may set his fancy a worke? and with modesty enough. We were all naked once, and must be so againe. I could sit for the naked Shepherdesse, with one Leg over the tother Knee, picking the Thorne out of her Foote most neatly, to make the Satyre peepe under.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well thou shalt have him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Mistris Philomel. Within.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let in the Boy. Now sir your newes?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The mad Knights Doctor Madam intreats to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now seekes he my assistance in his cure.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And Mr. Court-wit, and the other Gentlemen are below.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Goe you and entertaine the Gentlemen, while I consult with the Doctor, let him enter.

Now Mr. Doctor! you come to aske my counsell I know for your impatient Patient. But let me tell you first, the most learned Authors, that I can turne over; as Dioscorides, Avicen, Galen, and Hyppocrates are much discrepant in their opinions concerning the remedies for his disease.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madamâ

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Therefore I trust you'l pardon my weaknesse, if my opinion jumps not altogether with your judgement.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Madam, my purpose was notâ

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: My purpose is to advise you though, that, if his Frenzie proceed from love as you conjecture, that you administer of the rootes of Hellebore, destill'd together with Salt-peter, and the flowers of blind Netles, I'le give you the proportions, and the quantity is to take.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Mistake not me good Madamâ

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if his Malady grow out of ambition, and his over weening hopes of greatnesse (as I conjecture) then he may take a top of Cedar, or an Oake-apple is very soveraigne with the spirit of Hempseed.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Madam, I seeke no counsell in this case, my cunning isâ

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: To let me know, that that part of my house which I allow you is too little for you.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Shee's surely mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But you must claime possession of the rest, You are come to warne me out on't; are you not?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Mistake not so good Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Or do you call my attendance on his person, by way of a Nurse-keeper? I can do little service.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: For my part Madam I am sorry we are made the trouble of your house, and rather wish me out on't then your favour. But if your Ladyship will bee pleas'd to entertaine with patience the little I have to say.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Come to it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: First, let me tell you Madam, as 'tis manifest
You were the cause of his distraction,
Y'are bound in charity to yeild such meanes
(With safety of your honor and estate)
As you may render for his restoration
Which of all the earthly meanes depends on you
If I know any thing in my profession.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come to the point, you'ld have me visit him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: True Madam: for a sight of you, shall more
Allure his reason to him, then all medicine
Can be prescrib'd.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: By your favour sir, you say
Saving my honor and estate I am bound,
But may I with the safety of my Life,
And limbes, and a whole skin dare venture.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: My life o' that.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You might more safely lay
Lives of a hundred Patients.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Now hee's calme,
Now shall he see you, but at most secure
And modest distance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come for once i'le trust you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Come out into the Garden here; and let them talke within, I say he shall talke with her; and his belly full, and doe with her too, her belly full, for all thou: an honest discreet Gentleman, and thou a coward and a cockscombe. Besides he has an art and quality to live upon, and maintaine her Lady-like, when all thy money may be gone. And yet thou prat'st o' thy two thousand pound at use, when thou and thy money too are but an asse and's load tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well, you may speake your pleasure. This is no cause to fight for.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le make thee fight, or promise to fight with me, or somebody else before we part, or cut thee into pieces.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But tell me seriously dost thou love my Ladies woman so well as to marry her, and suffer the Picture-drawer now to court her privately, and perhaps to draw and carry her from thee?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why he here will have it so you see, and pull'd mee out.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: It is to doe a cure upon thee, coward.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Coward! pish! a common Name to men in buffe and feather. I scorne to answer to't.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why dost thou weare a Sword? only to hurt mens feet that kick thee?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay you are too severe.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace. I'le jowle your heads together, and so beat ton with tother else. Why dost thou were a Sword I say?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: To fight when I see cause.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Now he sayes something, yet, and may be curable.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What is a cause to fight for?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am not to tell you that sir, It must be found out and given me before I ought to take notice.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You may safely say for Religion, King or Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darst thou fight for Religion? say.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Who that has any Religion will fight I say?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I say thou hast none. Speake, hast thou any?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Truly, in this wavering world I know not how to answer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: La you. Hee'l say he has no King neither, rather then fight.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Why if he will not fight for him he is no Subject, and no Subject no King.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thanke you sir, I would ha' said so.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: O thou wouldst make a speciall Souldier now!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well sir, all are not choyce doggs that run, some are taken in to make up the cry.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And for thy Countrey, I dare sweare thou wouldst rather run it then fight for't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Run my Countrey I cannot, for I was borne i'the City. I am no clown to run my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darst thou tell me of clowns thou cockney chicken-hearted whelp thou?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Forbeare good sir, there are countrey Gentlemen as well as clownes, and for the rank I honour you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Sirrah you lie, strike me for that now; or I will beat thee abhominably.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Up to him man: wilt thou suffer all?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I wouldâ butâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You lie I say againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thinke I doe, I thinke I doe, and why should I maintaine an evill cause?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The wench thou lov'st and doatest on is a whore.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, if she be 'tis not my fault, nor hers: somebody else made her so then I warrant you. But should another man tell me so!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would say as much to him as to you. Nor indeed is any mans report of that a sufficient cause to provoke mee unlesse shee her selfe confess'd it, and then it were no cause at all.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a true City wit now.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I should have wit sir, and am acounted a wit within the walls, I am sure my Father was Master of his company, and of the wisest company too i'the city.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What company's that?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The Salters sir. For sal sapit omnia you know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Your Father was a cuckold tho', and you the Son of a whore.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fight now or you'l die infamous, was your Mother a whore?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Deny't and darst, say, was she not?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively shee might be in respect of some holy woman, the Lady Ramsey, Mistris Katherine Stubbs and such, ha, ha. Is that a cause?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What! not to say your Mother was a whore?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He may say his pleasure, It hurts her not: shee is dead and gone. Besides, at the best shee was but a woman, and at the worst shee might have her frailties like other women. And is that a cause for mee to fight for the dead, when wee are forbidden to pray for'em?

sp.speaker: Cou
sp.p: But were your Mother living now, what would you say or doe?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why, I would civilly ask her if she were a whore? If she confess'd it, then he were in the right, and I ought not to fight against him: for my cause were naught. If she deny'd it, then he were in an error, and his cause were naught, and I would not fight, 'twere better he should live to repent his errour.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Nay, now if I do not kill thee let me be hang'd for idlenesse. Draw.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hold I am unprepar'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I care notâ unlesse thou sweare presently, and without all equivocation upon this swordâ

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Scabberd and all I pray sir, The cover of the book is allowd in courts to sweare upon.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Well sir, now you shall sweare to challenge the next that wrongs you. sheathes it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, if the wrong give me sufficient cause.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Cause agen! suppose that fellow within should take your wench from you? which very likely he has done already: for I left 'em close on a couch together Kissing andâ

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Gi' me the booke, i'le have her from him, or him from her if he be without her belly, or Kill him if he be within her.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tis well a cause may be found at last tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I like a man, whom neither Lie, Kick, Battoune, scandall, Friends, or Parents, the wrongs of Countrey, King or Religion can move, that will, yet, fight for his
wench. Thou wilt be one of the stiffe blades o' the time I see.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A wench is a moving cause: Unseen

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, here helpeâ haâ Above.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why dost not draw and run in upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: After you I will sir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
