sp.p: A pox upon thee art thou down agen?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No sir, I am drawn you see.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Help, help, a rape, a rape, murder, help! Draw all

sp.speaker: Sw. Cou.
sp.p: Tis time to fly then.

div.stage: Enter Dainty (his sword drawne) and Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I come my Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What's the matter Phil?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What cry was that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Was it not you that caus'd it sir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Was it not here?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Was it not you that cry'd?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Is there helpe, helpe, helpe? Above.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O tis my Lady in the Madmans chamber. Is her mirth come to this?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Where, which way?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Here, here the dore's made fast. Exe. omnes

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le breake it open. Pret. Cit. his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Help here, help the Lady; help the Lady. Doctor looks out above.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: We are a comming, you shall have help enough
I warrant, what's the matter? you shall not lack for helpâ Florish his sword.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away Medusa. Hence, thou hast transformd me. Stone, stone, I am all stone. Bring morter and make a bul-wark of me. Above unseen

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O that's the Mad-man! How madly he talkes!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
Stones to make a bul-warke quoth a! If he had
but to make a brace of Demy-culvering bullets, they were thumpers I thinke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down, but reare me up, and make me my own statue.

div.stage: Enter Strangelove, Swain-wit, Court-wit, Dainty. Phil.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Was ever such a practice?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: A meere accident of madnesse.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I say it was a practise in the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yet he calld out for help.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You had broke up the dore first. That was but to colour his trechery.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A new way, and a very learned one I promise you; to cure madnesse with a plaister of warme Lady-gutts.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He would ha' had a mad bout with my Lady it seemes. He would ha' vented his madnes into her. And she could ha' drawn better then the Leaches.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: If you believe this Madam, tho' sir Ferdinand be by his madnesse excusable in the attempt, you ought to be reveng'd upon the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Let's cut him into pieces Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le think upon some way to make him a dreadfull example to all the Pandarean Doctors i' the Towne. Come in Gentlemen, and helpe mee with your advices.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: You shall want no advise Madam. No strength,
Let's goe sir. He snatcheth Phil. from Dainty, who took her by the arm.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: What mean you Mr. Cit-wit?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I have sworne. Therefore I say no more, but I have sworne. Exeunt Omnes;

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: THou art so honest, that I am asham'd
The vice of Anger blinded so my Reason,
As not to see through thy transparent breast
A true and noble heart; such as becomes
A Kinsman and a friend to her I love;
I can see now, and read thy integrity,
And, by the light of that th'inhumane false-hood
Of that Court-monster, that compacted piece
Of Rapine, pride and Lust.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Yet this is he
That did aspire to be a glorious Courtier.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Courtier? A meere vaine glorious imposture;
Pretending favour, having nothing lesse.
Witnesse his want of Merit. Merit only
It is that smoothes the brow of Majesty,
And takes the comfort of those precious beauties
Which shine from grace Divine: and hee's a Traytor
(No way to stand a courtier) that to feed
His Lusts, and Riots, works out of his Subjects
The meanes, by forging grants of the Kings favour.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What my master has suffer'd by his forgeries
I know to be the Shipwrack even of all
Except his Daughter, and what his ayme at her
Was I thinke appeares to you; And what she might
Have suffer'd by't we both may guesse: onely we hope
Her vertue would have bin a guard to her beauty.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Tis plaine he never lov'd her vertuously
That is fallen mad for another.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: That madnesse is his fate; which renders him into my masters hands to restore all agen. I, note the Justice of it.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But as his fortune by the others ruine
Shall be advanc'd, I shall be more rejected.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That foule mistrust much misbecomes a Love
Rejected sir? by whom? Charissa's constant to you,
And time will cleare his frownes: and put you on
Now, the same confidence you had before;
His wanting fortune rais'd a storme against you,
Your noble friend Sir Raphael has already
By learned reasons and court-oratory
Prevayl'd for you to visit her: and now
Y'are come within the verge o'th' house, do you shrinke?
See, a good Omen, they issue forth to meet you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I'le heare no more on't sir, and am much sorry
That so much Lip-labour is spent already
Upon so vaine a Subject.
Give me leave then
To wonder at your light inconstancy,
Your want of resolution: yea of judgement.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: He is flown off agen.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Did you not give me leave to send for him;
Who, now is come to tender his affection
Unto your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Did not you first promise Ferd: Char. and Gab. aside
To give assurance of fit joincture for her,
Proportionable to her dowry, which
You now are started from?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I understood not
Nor can yet understand more of her dowry
Then a thousand pound which her Unkle left her,
And answerably to that I will make good her joincture.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O you are short sir,
I meane to make her worth ten thousand more
Out of my estate in the mad Ferdinand.
Another ten thousand to redeeme my Land,
Ten thousand more, i'le keep in bank for purchace.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: A judgement's fallen upon him: Hee's mad too;
Struck lunatique with his o're-weening hopes
Sprung from the others misery.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And so sir, as you came you may depart:
For 'lesse you bring a thousand pound per annum
T'assure upon her, shee's no wife for you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: O sir, you had better left me in that peace
I lately slept in, without any hope
Of seeing her againe, then by your summons
To startle me back from a quiet death
To Kill me thus with Tantalizing tortures.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Thank then your learned friend, who fail'd me in
His undertaking for you, and for her
If walls and locks can hold her, she no more
Shall tantalize you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Wherein have I fail'd sir?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sir, in assuring joincture to her Dowry.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Sir to no possible dowry you can give her,
But you propound the estate you have i' th' Moon;
When shall you take possession, thinke you, of your
Lordship of Lunacy in the Cynthian Orbe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I shall climbe thither sir without the helpe
Of your Heaven-scaling ladder of Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nay then sir heare me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What in private sir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Remember, sweet, your vow.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Most constantly. And let mee conjure you by this. Kisse.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And thisâ

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That you forget not yours.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Quick, quick! i'le stand before you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: And time at length will point us out a meanes
After a short long-seeming separation
To meet and reunite our vowes and faiths
With greater strength and fervour.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Ha! i'le part you.
Was it for that you whisper'd, politick sir?
And couldst thou stand their screene? thou treacherous varlet out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: For what offence?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Darst thou expostulate?
Thou death deserving Villaine. Hurts him.
And Huswife get you in: you may depart sirs
Has your love blinded you? i'le lead you then.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madnesse at heighth.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Will you along!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O sir you are unkinde.
Love then a wilfull father is lesse blind. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Friend, has he hurt thee?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am sure I bleed for't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Why how now Frederick? despaire not man.
He has vex'd me; and out of my vexation
Shall spring thy comfort. I will labour for thee,
I'le study nothing more then to beguile
This watchfull fury; this Hisperian Dragon.
Say to thy selfe and boldly shee's thine owne,
And for thy meanes, (Basta) let me alone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You are my noble Patron.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Turn'd away:
As I was his servingman, I am rewarded;
Tis common with us creatures to serv'd so:
But, as I am no more his servant, I
Am free to vindicate my selfe out of
The wrong done to my blood (which is the same
With his,) by him rejected and despis'd.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Mendicant at home?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Not to be spoken with at this time sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Pray let him know that the Lady Strangelove
Requires him sodainly to remove his Madman
Out of her house; or shee must take a course
Much to his disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: This is a surly fellow, and tho' I have sworn
The humor of fighting is scarce warme in me yet,
And she advises him to find a better Doctor for him,
For this has taken a wrong course.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le tell't you as a secret. The Physitian thought to have cur'd his patient, (who has bin a notable Gamester at In and In) between my Ladies legs. If I and two or three more (but chiefly my selfe indeed) had not rescued her, the Doctor had held the Lady-cow to the Mad-bull.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He thinks I lie now. And should he gi' me the lie, the vertue of my Oath were questionable.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is this upon your knowledge sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: True upon my life. So farewell honest friend. Exit

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This may prove sport and businesse too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: We will do something sodainly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What if you take me into that something too?
I guesse it is some stratagem to beguile
The cautious father of his injur'd daughter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: This fellow will betray us.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I will venter
All that I have, my fortune in Charissa
On his his fidelity, sir his thoughts are mine.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Cupid and Mercury favour our designe. Ex. Om.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: YOur judgement (by your favour) Mr. Doctor
Much faild you in that case.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Your reason yet may plead
Mine innocence, that drew her but to visit him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: But that drew on his fury; and though reason
May argue much for you, shee can heare none,
Nor any understand: The swift affrightment
Upon her strength of passion, struck so deepe
A sense into her, that is has depriv'd her
Of all her proper senses. She is even mad sir.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Not past my cure; and by a present meanes
Pray, win her hither to see a madder object
Then is her selfe, and see how that will worke.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I'le gladly ad my paines unto your skill. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Come forth into the aire. Conduct him gently.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Into the aire! Set me upon Mount Lathmos,
Where I may see, and contemplate the beauty
Of my ador'd Diana; or carry me
Up to Hymettus top, Cytheron, Othris or Pindus
Where shee affects to walke and take the ayre;
Or tarry, stay, perhaps shee hunts to day
I' th' woods of Merathon, or Erymanthus.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: That's a long journey sir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Y'are a long bearded foole.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I thought I had been a Phisitian. But sir
You shall not need t' expose your selfe to travell,
Your Goddesse will descend into this Garden,
Passe but time here a while and shee'l come to you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: We will have joviall pastime. Shall we run
At base, or leape frog, or dance naked
To entertaine her, or what do you thinke
Of downe-right drinke and singing?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: That's best of all.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Let's have a mad catch then.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Here Madam may you see the Madmans Revels.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And after that the Doctors Tragicomedy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are not your wind pipes tun'd yet? Sing
A Catch.
So now a Dance, I am all ayreâ Ahaighâ Ahaigh
I thanke thee Mercury that hast lent thy wings
Unto my feete. Play me my Countrey Dance,
Stand all you by. These Lasses and these Swaines
Are for my Company.
sp.stage: He Dances a conceited Countrey Dance, first doing his honours, then as leading forth his Lasse. He danceth both man and womans actions, as if the Dance consisted of two or three couples, at last as offring to Kisse his Lasse, hee fancies that they are all vanish'd, and espies Strangelove.
sp.l: How now! all vanish'd, ha!
It is no mervaile that the lesser lights
Become obscur'd when Cynthia appeares,
Let me with Adoration fall before
Thy Deity great Goddesse.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Keepe him from me.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: You must approach no nearer sir. The Goddesse
Is not so confident in her Divinity
As to trust you in reach of her.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Keepe back sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What Hydras, Gorgons, and Chymaeras are you;
Centaures and Harpies that dare interpose
Between my hopes, and my felicity!

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Doctor, away with him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Carry him to his Chamber,
And hold him down. His raging fit is on him

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Was Night made to surprise men at Noon-day?
Or shall the charmes of Heccate take force
To dimne Appolle's brightnesse? So't must be,
When Gods themselves give way to Destine. Exiunt with Ferd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: They are enough to hold, and binde him too. Swa. pulls back the Doctor.
Come you afore the Lady.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What's her pleasure?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Tis to do Justice upon thee O Doctor
Stirre, or cry out, or give the least resistance,
And I will cut thy head off before judgement.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What outrage doe you intend?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Outrage! Can you thinke of an outrage above the horror you offerd to this Lady, To violate her chastity? her honor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You cannot say so.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tis said, and you are guilty. Proceed to judgement Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I first would heare your censures.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: And mine among the rest good Madam. I have taken care that a new Doctor shall be brought. Therefore in the first place my censure is, that this be presently hang'd out o' the way.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: That's too high straind. What thinke you Madam, if to rectify his judgement, wee pick'd all the errours of his braine; First, opening the Pericranion, then take out the cerebrum; wash it in Albo vino, till it be throughy clens'd; and thenâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pox o' your Albo vino, and his cerebrum taking out, that were a way to kill him. Wee must not be guily of the death of a Dogleach, but have him purg'd a safer way.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: How? Proceed.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
We will fill his belly full of Whey, or Butter-milke, put him naked into a Hogs-head, then put into
the same an hundred broken Urinalls, then close up the Vessell and roll your Garden with it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I trust they cannot meane any such mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Hearke yee Gentlemen. Do you heare? A Guelders horne.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes Madam; tis a Sowgelder.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Fetch in that Minister of Justice.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Who Madam? the Sowgelder?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Wee'l make a Doctor guelder of him tho', and my Lady be so minded.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That will be sport indeed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But will you see the execution Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why not as well as other women have
Seene the dissections of Anotamies,
And executed men rip'd up and quarter'd?
This spectacle will be comicall to those.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: They dare not doe the thing they would have me feare.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Now Doctor you look heavily methinks,
You shall be lighter by two stone presently.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You will not murder me?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Stirre not; nor make least noyse
As you hope ever to be heard agen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I would I could pray now to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: I have brought him. The rarest fellow Madam,
And doe you thanke your fortune in him Doctor,
For he can sing a charme (he sayes) shall make
You feele no paine in your libbing or after it:
No Tooth-drawer, or Corne-cutter did ever worke
With so little feeling to a Patient.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Sing then, he shall not suffer without a Song.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What must he be stript now; or will letting down his breeches be enough?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You dare not use this violence upon me
More rude then rage of Prentices.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Doctor it is decreed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You cannot answer it.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Better by Law then you can the intent Guelder whets his knife and all in preparation, Linnen, Bason, &c.
Of Rape upon the Lady.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That was not to have beene my act, nor was it done.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: When this is done wee'l talke w' ye, come lay him crosse this Table. Hold each of you a Leg of him, and hold you your peace Dodipoll. And for his armes let me alone, do you work Guelder.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Hold, I have a secret to deliver to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You shall be deliver'd of your secrets presently.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: If I tell her not that shall give her pardon
Then let me suffer. Heare me sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Forbeare him, let him down.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Sweet sayst? Thou art not i'le be sworne.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well sir your weighty secret now to save your trifles.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: In private I beseech you Madam: for I dare but whisper't.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You shall allow me so much warinesse as to have one at least to be my Guard, and witnesse.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: This Gentleman then Madam.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We are shut out of councell.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: No matter. I list not be no nearer him: no more wou'd my cozen had he my nose. But where's Mr. Dainty and your finicall Mistris Phil all this while tho'?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No matter, but I ha' sworn you know. Therefore I say no more, but I have sworn.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What a strange tale is this! I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
I doe, and did before suspect it: and fram'd this counterfet plot upon you, Doctor, to worke out the
discovery: would I ha' seene you guelt dee think? That would have renderd mee more brutish then the women Barbers. Looke sir this is no Guelder, but one of my house Musick. (Goe, your part is doneâ Exit .And for th' affright you gave me, Doctor, I am even w'ye.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The Devill fright him next for a spurging, skitter-brooke. 'T were good you would call to burne some perfumes Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But for the secret you have told me i'le keepe it secret yet, I will keepe you so too; and from your Patient. Enter Boy.
There's a new Docter come already Madam to the madman.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: From sir Andrew Mendicant?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: His servant brought him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: I pray what Doctor is it?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ingage your selfe with no desire to know,
But, for the good you finde, fit thanks to owe;
So come with me, and come you Gentlemen. Ex. Omnes

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Frederick in a Doctors habit, Gabriel with two swords under his cloake, Ferdinand upon a Bed bound, and held down by servants.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: HEape yet more Mountaines, Mountaines upon
Mountaines, Pindus on Ossa, Atlas on Olympus,
I'le carry that which carries Heaven, do you
But lay't upon me!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Forbeare you'l stifle him,
Take off the needlesse weight of your rude bodies;
Unbind him and stand off, to give him ayre.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Sir though you are a Phisitian, I am no foole.
Take heede what you doe. Hee's more then six of us hold when his hot fit's upon him. He would now teare you to pieces should you let him loose.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: The danger then be mine. Let him sit up. Is not he civill now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I, for how long? do you note that Hercules eye there?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I charge you quit the roome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: 'Tis but to come agen when we are call'd.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Be not within the hearing of a call,
Or if you chance to heare me, though I cry
Murder, I charge you come not at me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Tis but a Doctor out o' the way; and that's no losse while there are so many, the best cannot live by the worst.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Keep the dore fast. You are much mist abroad sir,
And chiefly by the Ladies, who now want
The Court-ships, Banquets, and the costly presents
In which you wonted to abound to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Haâ

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Nay, nay, sit still sir. They say y'are mad;
Mad with conceit of being a favorite
Before your time, that is, before you had merit
More then a tumour of vaine-glory in you,
And in especiall care for your recovery
I am sent to administer unto you: but first
To let you blood. Dagger.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Ho! Murder, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Are you so sensible already? do not stirre
Nor cry too loud. Dos the meere apprehension
Of blood-letting affright your madnesse? Then
Reason may come agen.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: The Battaile of Musleborough Field was a brave one.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O do you fly out agen?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.stage: Sings part of the old Song, and acts it madly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: This is pretty: but back from the purpose.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Will you come to the point sir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: We but lose time in this sir: Though it be good testimony of your memory in an old Song. But do you know me?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Not know my Soveraigne Lord? Curs'd be those Knees, and hearts that fall not prostrate at his Feete.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This wild submission no way mittigates
My wrongs, or alters resolution in me
To Cure or Kill you quickly. Do you know me now sir?
Or have you known Charissa? do you start sir? Off his beard & gown.
There's signe of reason in you then: But bee't
By reason or by chance, that you awake
Out of your frantick slumber, to perceive me,
My cause and my Revenge is still the same,
Which I will prosecute according to
My certaine wrong, and not your doubtfull reason,
Since reasonlesse you layd those wrongs upon me
When you were counted wise, great, valiant, and what not
That cryes a Courtier up, and gives him power
To trample on his betters.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Who talkes this mortall to? I am a spirit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Sure I shall finde you flesh, and penetrable.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I would but live to subdue the Pisidians,
And so to bring the Lydians under tributeâ

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: You would but live t'abuse more credulous fathers
With courtly promises, and golden hopes
For your own lustfull ends upon their Daughters.
Thinke (if you can thinke now) upon Charissa.
Charissa who was mine, in faith and honour
Till you ignobly (which is damnably)
By a false promise with intent to whore her
Diverted her weake Father from the Match
To my eternall losse. Now whether you
Have wit or no wit to deny't, or stand to't,
Or whether you have one, or ten mens strength,
Or all, or none at all i'le fight or Kill you
Yet like a Gentleman, i'le call upon you Throw away his dags.
Give me the Swords. They are of equall length
Take you free choyce.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Pish. Run back.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I cast that to you then. Hand it, or die a Madman.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: O ho, ho, ho,â

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: All this sir to a Madam.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I have a cause to be more mad then he,
And in that cause i'le fight.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: He knowes not what you tell him.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I tell't the Devill in him then to divulge it
When I have dispossest him. I have further
Reason to kill him yet, to crosse your Master,
Who has beg'd his Estate. Now fight or die a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Hold Frederick hold. Thou hast indeed awak'd
Me to see thee and my selfe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Hee's not so mad to fight yet I see that.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: I'm glad you are your selfe sir, I shall fight
Now upon honorable tearmes, and could
Suppose before your madnesse counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yet hold. Has Mendicant beg'd me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: During your madnesse. What should hinder him?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Put up thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Upon no tearmes, and you alive.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Not to obtaine Charissa?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: As you Guest sir.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: It shall be by meanes if gold can win
Her Fathers grant.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That's most unquestionable.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Not that I dare not fight, doe I urge this,
But that the other is your safer way.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Your gold's too light. I will accept of nothing
From you while you dare tell me you dare fight,
Perhaps you doubt of ods, goe forth. Nay I
Will lock him out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You may: For I dare trust you while I go call the Lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Now are you pleas'd, or dare you now to fight sir?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I neither will nor dare fight in this cause.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: This is a daring Courtier!
How durst you wind your selfe in so much danger?
And why take madnesse in you, to be bound,
And grapled with so rudely?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Keepe my councell,
And take Charissa.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Tis a faire condition.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: First, for the wrong I did thee, noble youth
In my designe against Charissa's honour,
It is confess'd, repented; and her selfe
For satisfaction to be given to thee,
I'le fall upon thy Sword else, or be posted,
And Ballated with all disgrace.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Well yet.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: And for my shew of madnesse; 'twas put on
For my revenge on this impetuous Lady
To coole these flames (as much of anger as
Desire) with her disdaine, and tempting malice
Had rais'd within mee.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You would have ravish'd her.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I rather thought, she like a cunning Lady
Would have consented to a Madman, who
She might presume could not impeach her honor
By least detection. Monkeyes, Fooles, and Madmen,
That cannot blab, or must not be believ'd
Receave strange favours.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: And on that presumption
You fain'd your madnesse.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: But rather then to faile,
With your bawd Doctors helpe you would ha' forc'd her:
And that's the councell you would have me keep
On your assurance of Charissa to me:
That your proceeding in your madnesse here,
May yet finde meanes and opportunity
To exercise your violence.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Suppose so.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: Thou art not worth my Killing now.
Justice will marke thee for the Hangmans Office:
Nor, were Charissa in thy gift, were shee,
In that, worth mine or any good acceptance,
And for your councell, had within there Madam.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Frederickâ

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.l: The Lady of the house! where are you?
Will you be pleas'd to heare a secret Madam?
Strangely discover'd?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I doe not slight your act in the discovery,
But your imposture sir, and beastly practise
Was before whisper'd to me by your Doctor
To save his Epididamies.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O your pardon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am disgrac'd, undone.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Tis in my power
To make you the perpetuall shame of Court;
And will assuredly doe't, if you comply not
With me to make this injur'd Gentlemans fortune
In his belov'd Charissa.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Madam most readily, I have offer'd it.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: I have forecast the way and meanes already:
Which we must prosecute with art and speed.
Good ends oft times doe bad intents succeede.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I'le be directed by you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Noblest Lady. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: COme Sir, must I take you in hand agen?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: My Lady will convery her Madman to sir Andrew Mendicants it seemes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tell mee that I know not; and answer my questions.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Shee and the Doctor, and the tother Doctor's gone with him too.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Leave you by flim flams, and speake to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You know I ha' sworne. Doe you not know I ha' sworne?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: To live and die a beaten Asse; a coward hast thou not?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Prethee forbeare him: Hee's not worth thy anger.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Anger! Is every Schoole-master angry that gives Discipline with correction?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Would he were at Pensans agen.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Didst not thou tell my Lady that I was a coward in my own Countrey, and Kick'd out of Cornewall?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively I thinke I did in respect of Corineus, that wrastled and threw Giant after Giant over the cliffs into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pox o' your comparative lies; And didst not thou say that he here was pepper'd so full o' the whatsha callums, that his spittle would poyson a Dog or a Rat?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That was comparatively too in respect of a pure Virgin; a chrisome child or so.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He never shall move me, I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Meerly comparatively I speake it.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' mee for swearing i'le make thee speake positively, or beat thee superlatively before I ha' done with thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Ladyâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Hold a little. Didst thou not say this child here was a Pickpocket? and that he pickt thine of thy money, and thy watch, when he was singing betweene thy Leggs to day?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who I a Pick-pocket? Flies at him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Forbeare good Lady it was comparatively.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A pick pocket?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare and hear him Hercules.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Lend me a sword i'le kill him, and heare him afterwards.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay I must hold you then. How was hee comparatively your Pick-pocket?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That is as much as any man I know; That is I accuse nobody; that is all are as innocent as the child, and hee as the innocent unborne. And let that satisfy you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Live. I am satisfied. Now Gentlemen my Lady prayes you to follow her to sir Andrew Mendicants.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I know the businesse, 'Tis about our Revells.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Suffer a child to beat thee!

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: His cause was bad you know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Incorrigible coward! Say now; art not thou thy selfe a pick-pocket, and a cut-purse? say.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively it may be said, I am to a Church-warden, a Collector for the poore or such.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The conclusion is, that if ever I heare thou mentionst my name agen in any sense whatsoever, i'le beat thee out of reason.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: In my good wishes, and prayers I may: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Not in your prayers sir, shall you mention me, you were better never pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid I should then!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And make thine Oath good on that slie fellow that has taine away thy wench, orâ

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He has not tane her yet.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You ha' not seene her or him these two houres; has not my Lady call'd too, and shee not to be found?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: True, true: and if I be not reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Do't then now, while thou art hot. Shee comes, here take, and keepe her while thou art hot and hast her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is she at your dispose sir? Court takes aside with Dainty.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Your Lady gave you me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Or am in her gift?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You are in my possession, nor shall Lucifer dispossesse me of her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: So valiant on a sodaine!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Have I not cause?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You'l have me with all faults?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, and a match forever. Kisse.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: How meanes shee by all faults?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: A word shee alwayes uses in waggery.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: By all meanes take her from him. What! affraid of a coward?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You must do't or take the share, hee should ha' had a down-right beating. Forgi' me for swearing, hee's a veryer coward then tother.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Hee will serve the better to flesh him. And do but note his tiranicall rage that is the vanquisher.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You will on.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir shee is mine by promise.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Shee's mine by act and deed sir according to the flesh, let her deny't and she can.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: That shall be try'd by Law.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: By Law of armes and hands it shall, take that, and let her goe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Beare witnesse Gentlemen he struck me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O pittifull Picture-drawer!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Will you not draw? I will then. Draw.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What would you have sir? If shee be yours take her.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That's not enough, I will make thee fight, what blindnesse have I liv'd in! I would not but be valiant to be Cesar.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: O brave Cit, O brave Cit.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why dost not draw thou fellow thou?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Shee's his he sayes; and she denies it not, shall I fight against him for his own?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le make thee fight, or cut thee into pieces.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He turnes your words over to him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why dost thou weare a sword? onely to hurt mens feet that Kick thee? Kick.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Doe you observe? Nay thou art too severe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace, i'le jowle your heads together and so beat ton with tother else.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for swearing. Hee'l beat's all anon.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why dost thou weare a Sword I say?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Some other time sir, and in fitter place.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sirrah you lie, strike me for that, or I will beat thee abominably.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You see this Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And I see't too, was ever poor wench so couzend in a man?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The wench thou lov'st and doat'st on is a whore.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No, no, That was not right, your father was a cuckold tho', and you the sonne of a whore.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Good, I shall love this fellow.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I can take all this upon account.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You count all this is true then. Incorrigible coward! what was the last vile name you call'd mee Mr. Swain-wit? O I remember, sirrah thou art a Pick-pocket and a Cut-purse; And gi' me my money agen, and him his or I will cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I am discover'd.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Doe you answer nothing, doe you demurre upon't?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Hold sir I pray; Gentlemen so you will grant me pardon, and forbeare the Law i'le answer you.

sp.speaker: Cou. Sw.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: It is confess'd; I am a Cut-purse.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Comparatively or positively doe you speake?
Speake positively, or I will beat thee superlatively.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for swearing a brave Boy.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Here is your Watch, and Money; And here is yours. Now as you are Gentlemen use no extremity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Beyond all expectation!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: All thought.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Miraculous! O the effects of valour!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Was ever woman so mistaken o' both sides?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But dost thou thinke thou art valiant for all this tho'?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You were best try; or you, or both, or come all three.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I sweare thou shalt have it to keepe up while thou art up.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Is this your picture-drawing? are you the Kings Picture-drawer? A neat denomination for a Cut-purse, that drawes the Kings Pictures out of men Pockets.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come sir, come in with us.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Pray use me Kindly Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, wee will use you in your kind sir.

div.stage: Takes Phil by the hand. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: ACT. V. SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Mendicant, a Letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: THis is the day of my felicity,
And is the same with that the Poet Sings
Is better then an Age. Come forth Charissa,
Now you appeare my comfort; and I can
No lesse then thanke thy sweet obedience
That hast comply'd with my directions,
Bride-like and glorious to meet a fortune,
So great as shall beget the present envy
Of all the Virgin Ladies of the Court,
And a posterity, that through all ages,
Shall praise and magnify thy act.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Your acceptation of my duty sir
Is all that I can glory in.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How are we bound unto this noble Lady
That sent us our instructions.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sure I am. If this be a true Coppy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Let Musick in her soft but sweetest notes
Usher their welcome, whilst unto my thoughts Musick
The lowdest harmony resounds my triumph.
sp.stage: Enter Doctor, and Fred. in Doctors habit, Strange. Priest, Ferd. in the chair as before borne by servants, Fab. as one of the servants.
sp.l: Madam most welcome.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: In fewest and the softest words sir Andrew.
(He sleepes) and let him gently be convey'd
Onely with those about him to his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Charissa, go: be you his conduct, softly, softly,
I see y'ave brought a Priest Madam. Ext. Om. Pret.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: By all best reason, Mend. & Strang.
For when we found he us'd Charissa's Name,
When he was calme and gentle, calling still
Charissa! where's Charissa? a good space
Before he slept, and being then demanded
What would he with Charissa? He most readily
Reply'd, Fetch me Charissa and a Priest.
The Doctors in their judgements (unto which
My full opinion assented) might
Foresee, that in removing him, where she
Might be his immediat object, when he wakes,
That fresher flames to instant marriage
Would then arise.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Incomparably judicious Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yet not without your leave would I attempt it;
Without your leave, knowing your watchfull care
Over your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And that care of mine
Was (Madam) by your favour
Principall motive to this great effect.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Take all unto your selfe, I am content.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'd faine steale in and watch th' event of things.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: But have you heard sir Andrew the mischance
Of the unfortunate Lover, distracted Frederick?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How! what of him?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: H'has made himselfe away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: (Hee has by this time, or the Priest is tongue-ty'd.)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He has left no estate worth begging, that's the worst of't.
My joyes come flowing no meâ yet I would see.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And heare me good Sir Andrew, for the Love
I bring to ad unto your joyes: for I
Foreseeing the event of this nights happinesse
Have warn'd some friends to follow me with Revells
To celebrate the Marriage of your fortunes.
See they are come. Pray entertaine 'em sir.

div.stage: Enter Court. Swayn. Cit-wit, Dainty, Phil. Boy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The Gallants that were to day so merry with mee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: The same: but very harmelesse.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: All but one sir. Did you not lose your purse to day?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Cou. Sw.
sp.p: Wee'l tell you Madam.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My purse? (I mist it at my Lady Strangeloves.)

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This Picture-drawer drew it, and has drawne more of the Kings-pictures then all the Limners in the Towne. Restore it sirrah.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not take it, 'twas my neglect that lost it, not he that stole it. This is my day of fortune; it comes home to me; more then I dare receive. O my joyes, let me be able to containe you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ha' you another purse to lose?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have a purse; which if I lose, i'le blame my selfe, none else.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Let him but come so neare you as to aske forgivenesse for the last, and if he doe not take the next, though it be six fadome deepe i' your pocket i'le hang for him when his time comes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'le watch his fingers for that. Sit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Observe good Madam.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir at your feet I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It needs not, prithee rise.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.l: Never, till you pronounce that happy word
I pardon thee: or let me have some token
Of sweet assurance that I am forgiven
Which I beseech youâ I beseech you grant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: In sooth thou hast it. Heaven pardon thee as I doe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I have it sit indeed, and as your gift i'le keepe it, promising before all these witnesses, i'le never venter for another.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fore me an expert fellow; Pitty he should be hang'd before we have more of his breed.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Did not I tell you sir? And these are but his short armes; i'le undertake, when he makes a long arme, he shall take a purse twelve skore off.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I doe not like Thieves handsell though, This may presage some greater losse at hand.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen you know your taske, be expeditious in't.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I have cast the designe for't already Madam. My inventions are all flame and spirit. But you can expect no great matter to be done extempore or in six minutes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What matter ist so wee skip up and downe? our friend Jack Dainty here, Mr. Cut-purse dances daintily tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: And Mr. Cit-wit, you have worthily wonne my woman sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I have her Madam, she is mine.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le make her worth a thousand pound to you, besides all she has of her own.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Her faults and all Madam, we are agreed o' that.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Suppose this Boy be mine.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would he were else, that I might have him under lawfull correction, and the cause o' my side: for he beat me not long since.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And you be my father, and do not make much of me and give me fine things, i'le beat you agen so I will; and my mother shall helpe me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Agree'd Billy, agreed Philly. Never was man so sodainly, so rich; Nay never looke Gentlemen, shee is mine, and hee's mine own, I am sure I ha' got him now; And all faults are salv'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Her word in waggery is made good in earnest now tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: To your busines Gentlemen; if you have a They consult .short speech or two, the boy's a prety Actor; and his mother can play her part; women-Actors now grow in request. Sir Andrew! melancholly?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I was thinking on the omen of my purse. Court draws his Tables and retires to Phil, writes & sometimes shewes her.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Fear no further mishap sir; tis ominous to feare.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray let's go in and see how things proceed.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Pray give mee leave to make the first discovery;
Walke downe into the Garden, i'le come to you;
And here are some would speak with you. Ex. severally.

sp.p: Into the Garden, good, let's follow him.
Tis not the repulse he gave us in the morning shall quit him of us.
No now his superintendent's turn'd away, wee'l once more fill his head with millions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I'le make the Dance, and give you all the footing. Practise footing.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Stand further off o' my Pocket tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No matter if we lose any thing, and he within ten miles of us i'le make him answer't.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I want a fift man, I would have an od.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: The Marriage is perform'd. The Priest has done his officeâ

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Doctor can you dance?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: And sing too, I ha' forgot much else.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I'le speak the Speech: Ha' not I forgot my Actors tone tro? I shal remember't, I could have acted 'em all ore.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I can speak a Speech too Mother, must I call you Mother now?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I my Boy, now I dare vouch thee.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: What think you of this tune sir for your dance?
Tay dee, dee, &c.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.l: I'le borow a Violl and take it of you instantly. Ex.
Pray sir, is sir Andrew Mendicant i' the house. To Court-w.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Umhâ He writes in his tables sometimes scratching his head, as pumping his Muse. Is he within sir, can you tell? He's too busie it seemes.
sp.l: Can you tell me sir I pray, if sir Andrew be within? To Cit-wit as he mov'd toward him, Cit-wit Dances looking on his Feete, &c.
Very strange! among what Nation am I arriv'd?
Here's one in civill habit sure will answer me,
Sir may I be inform'd by you? saw you sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Te precor domine Doctor. He sings on. The Doctor stretches his Throat in the Tune.
They are no Christians sure.
Sir may I be inform'd by you? To Swayn. He whistels & Dances Sellingers round, or the like.
Blesse me; the people are bewitch'd.
Do you belong to the house sir? To Dainty, he fidls to him & the 4 dancing & singing practise about him.
I hope for curtesie here Lady wil you be pleas'dâ To Phil. she speaks in a vile tone like a Player.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O by no meanes, we must speake Charon faire,
Or hee'l not waft us o're the Stigian Floud,
Then must we have a sop for Cerberus
To stop his yawning Chaps; Let me alone
To be your Convoy to Elizium.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: This is most heathenish of all. Dainty playes softly & Doctor with him aside.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'le pass that snarling triple-headed Cur
Which keeps the pallace-gate of Pluto's Court,
And guide you safe through pitchy Acheron.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What Woman Monster's this? Sweete young Gentleman, let me aske you a question.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Grim death, why rather didst thou not approach
My younger dayes; before I knew thy feares?
Thy paines are multiplied by our yeares.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: All Lunatick? or Gentlemen, do you want leasure
Or civility to answer me?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ha' you done the speeches Mr. Court wit?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: I have already from the forked top
Of high Parnassus fetcht 'em.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: And shall my wife and Billi boy speake 'em?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: As i'le instruct you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You write admirably I confesse; But you have an ill tone to instruct in; I'le read to 'em my selfe, you give your words no grace.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: You have the tune right, will you instruct the Musick men?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: And you all in the Dance imediately.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: But shall we have no silken things, no whim whams
To Dance in tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Perhaps the Bride can furnish us.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: With some of her old Petticotes, can she?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No, no my Lady has tane care for all.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Come, come away to practise, and be ready. Exe. Om. Fidling, Footing, Singing, Acting, &c.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Never was I in such a Wildernesse.
But my revenge upon Sir Mendicant
Shall answer all my patience, in the Jeere
I meane to put upon him.
I will possesse him with a braine-trick, now, wherein
A meere invention of mine own
Heaven pardon me for lying) shall so nettle him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Goe back and be not seene till I come to you. Ex. Pro.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hee's come. Ha' you heard the newes sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What sir Raphael?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That Ferdinand's restor'd to's wits.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Do you take the losse of his estate so mildly
Which might ha' bin your own?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I hope you thinke mee a Christian sir, but how should he arrive at such a sodaine knowledge of it, if it be so? I will pretend tis true, yes sir, he is in's wits.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I thought I had ly'd when I did prophesie:
But sir my Nephew Fredrickâ

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Has made himselfe away, I heard o' that too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: (I hope not so) yet there's another accident
Of which you have not heard, may touch you nearer,
And that indeed's my businesse, you sir, furiously
Wounded your Man to day.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not dangerously I hope.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Flatter not so your selfe; Hee's on the point of dying.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nor be too much dejected,
His life you may get off for (as 'twas done
In heat of blood) marry sir your estate
(You'l pardon me) is beg'd; my selfe has don't,
And therein, beg'd the Begger.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Take not too deepe a sense of it: For if you'l yeild
That Frederick yet shall have it with your Daughter,
I will remit the Estate.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O is it so?
Do you move this for a dead man?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No, he lives.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Do you practise on me? Madam where are

div.stage: Enter Strange. Ferd. Fred. Charissa. Gabriel behind.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Here sir, and am become your Usher to such guests you?
As you must bid most welcome. Mend. stands amaz'd

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: She here! i'm then agen confounded.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Nay sir Raphael, I potest we will be friends notwithstanding I have outstript you in your plot of matching your Nephew Frederick, here to his love Charissa.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But is it so?â

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: It is, in which I hope sir you are not offended,
Who gave me leave by any opportunity
To take her, I broke no locks nor walls for her.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, and your blessing sir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And is it so with you sir Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: It is, and sir in testimony of my recovery, I make demand of my estate: of which you thought your selfe possest.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What hopes am I fallen from? and what misery fallen into; when the little I have is beg'd for Man-slaughter!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I quit you of that sir.

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: How couldst thou deale so with me?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: To shew my gratitude.
You overpaid me for all my former services,
For which I justly thought I ought you this.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Nor thinke your Daughter undervalued sir,
Three thousand pound I give him to augment
Her fortune in him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Dreames, dreames, All these are waking Dreames.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: All reall truth sir, whither flie you from us?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Am I of all defeated; and by all
Abus'd and mock'd? More roome there: let mee goe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You mistake strangely. Florish.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Harke! the Revellers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That come to celebrate your joyes, which wilfully
You will not apprehend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tis all but shew, Let go, and I will do
Something shall ad to your delight imediatly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let him goe and weare out his fit by himselfe. Florish.

div.stage: Enter Boy, and Philomel, as Cupid and Venus.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Venus and Cupid, my Mother and Iâ
Helpe me.â I have it now.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I
Helpe me agen; Noe, no, no.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I,
Let me alone.
Venus and Cupid my Mother and I.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There's an Actor now!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How doubtfull of himselfe; and yet how perfect he was!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: A selfe mistrust is a sure step to Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Sententious sir Raphel.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Quarrells are ended Madam.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Come hither Cupid.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: From my Italian Mount I did espy
(For what is hidden from a Deity?)
How faintly Hymen did his Office here
Joyning two Lovers with the hand of feare;
Putting his Torch out for obscurity;
And made the Chamber (which belongs to me)
His Temple. But from hence let feare remove.
See here, the Champions for the Queene of Love.
Courage 1 1 1 Swain, sent from Mars; The Muses 2 2 2 Court. kill.
From wise Apollo. And the God, which still
Inspires with subtilty, sly Mercury
Sends this his Agent 3 3 3 Dainty.. Here's Activity 4 4 4 Cit-wit.
From Jupiter 5 5 Doctor himselfe; And from her store
Of Spies, the Moon sends This to keepe the dore.
With Art of Action, now, make good the place,
In right of Love to give the Nuptialls Grace.

div.stage: After they have Danc'd a while, Enter Projectors, breakes 'em off.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lay by your Jolity, forbeare your Sport,
And heare a story shall inforce your pitty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What black Tragedian's this?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Some Nuntius sent from Hell.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: One of my Masters Minions, a Projector.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: You had a Master: But to all I speake.
Your practises have sunk him from the Comforts
Of all his hopes in fortune, to the Gulfe
Of deepe despaire; from whence he rose inflam'd
With wild distraction and phantastick fury.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hee's mad; is he?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Mad, and has hang'd himselfeâ

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Alas my Father.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How! hang'd himselfe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: All over sir, with draughts of Projects, Suits,
Petitions, Grants, and Pattents, such as were
The Studies and the Labours of his Life,
And so attir'd he thinks himselfe well arm'd
T'incounter all your scornes.

div.stage: Enter Mendicant attir'd all in Patents; A Wind-mill on his head, and the other Projector.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Roome here: a Hall for a Monopolist,
You, Common-wealths informers lead me on.
Bring me before the great Assembly. See,
Fathers Conscript, I present all I have
For you to cancell.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a brave shew, and out-shines our devise.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is a Patent for the taking of poor John and Barrell-cod alive, and so to preserve 'em in salt-water for the benefit of the Fishmongers.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: There's salt in this.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I this has some savour in't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is a fresh one sir, For the catching, preservation, and transportation of Butter-flies: whereby they may become a native commodity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: That's a subtle one.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is for profits out of all the Common-Cryes i' th' City, As ofâ Oystersâ Codlingsâ wood to cleave, Kitching stuffe, and the thousand more, even to the Matches for your Tinder-box, and all Forrainers to pay double; And a Fee out of the Link-boyes profits. But no cries to escape. Tis for a peace.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What if some should cry Murder, murder?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Or Theeves, theeves?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Or Fire, fire?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Or women cry out five Loves a penny?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: All all should pay. But I submit
My selfe to you most honorable censure.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What dos he take us for?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Powers, Powers; A lower house at least.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And all my patents to be conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Our Projects would not take with you, wee'l take yours tho'.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: He shall dance out of 'em: Musick! Play out our Dance, we will disrobe you presently.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, and dismantle his Projectors too.

div.stage: They all Dance. In the Dance they pull off his Patents; And the Projectors Clokes, who appeare all ragged. At the end of the Dance the Projectors thrust forth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: An excellent Morrall! The Projects are all cancel'd, and the Projectors turnd out o' dores.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: True Gallants, and now I am my selfe agen,
I saw th'event of all with good esteeme.
And would as well as you a Madman seeme,
And now my blessings on your Son and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: This Bride, Dame Venus here, cooles all this while tho'.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: By Mr: Bride-groomes leave, i'le stirre her blood a little for the good meaning shee had towards me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: You may doe so. He dare's not pick her pocket,
And for her Maidenhead I dare trust him tho' he should
Dance quite out of sight with her.

div.stage: While they Dance the rest confer.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Tis well: And all are friends.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You have my protestation: and in that,
Madam, my faith before these noble friends.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Upon those honourable tearmes sir Ferdinando I will be yours.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sheel 'have him, it seemes at last.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Shee's a wise widdow by't: for sure enough, she saw something in his mad naked fit, when hee put her to't, to choose a husband by, wo' not out of her thought yet.
What is there more to say now Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You question well.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But to Supper and to bed?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You consider well.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: We have had other pastime enough.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You reason well, Would all were pleas'd as well
T' absolve that doubt, to those we must appeale.

sp.speaker: Strang.
sp.l: LAdyes, your suffrages I chiefly crave
For th'humble Poet. Tis in you to save
Him, from the rigorous censure of the rest,
May you give grace as y'are with Beauty blest.
True: Hee's no dandling on a Courtly lap,
Yet may obtaine a smile, if not a clap.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I'm at the Cavaliers. Heroick spirits,
That know both to reward, and atchieve merits,
Do, like the Sun-beames, vertuously dispense
Upon the lowest growths their influence,
As well as on the lofty: our Poet so
By your Phebean favours hopes to grow.

sp.speaker: Cit-w.
sp.l: And now you generous spirits of the City
That are no lesse in money then braine wity,
My selfe, my Bride, and pretty Bride-boy too,
Our Poet for a Boun preferres to you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And though you tast of no such Bride-ale Cup,
He hopes y' allow the Match to be clapt up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: And, if this Play be naught (yes so he said)
That I should gi' yee my Mother for a Mayd.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p:
And why you now? or you? or you? I'le speak enough for you all, you now would tell the Audients they should not feare to throng hither the next day: for you wil secure their Purses cut-free, and their pockets pick-free. Tis much for you to do tho'. And you would say that all
your projects are put down, and you'l take up no new: but what shall be (spectators) to please you. And you Poetick part induces you, t'appologize now for the Poet too, as they ha' done already, you to the Ladies, you to the Cavaliers and Gentry; you to the City friend, and all for the Poet, Poet, Poet, when alls but begging tho. I'le speak to 'em all, and to my Countrey folkes too if here be any o'em: and yet not beg for the Poet tho', why should we? has not he money for his doings? and the best price too? because we would ha' the best: And if it be not, why so? The Poet has shewd his wit and we our manners. But to stand beg, beg for reputation for one that has no countenance to carry it, and must ha' money is such a Pastime!â If it were for one of the great and curious Poets that give these Playes as the Prologue said, and money too, to have 'em acted; For them, indeed, we are bound to ply for an applause. Because they look for nothing else, and scorn to beg for themselves. But then you'l say those Playes are not given to you; you pay as much for your seats at them as at these, though you sit nere the merrier, nor rise the wiser, they are so above common understanding; and tho' you see for your love you will judge for your money, why so for that too, you may. But take heed you displease not the Ladies tho' who are their partiall judges, being brib'd by flattering verses to commend their Playes; for whose faire cause, and by their powerfull voyces to be cry'd up wits o' Court, the right worshipfull Poets boast to have made those enterludes, when for ought you know they bought 'em of Universitie Scholars tho', and onely shew their own wits in owning other mens; and that but as they are like neither. As thus, do you like that Song? yes. I made it. Is that Scene or that Jest good? Yes, Twas mine; and then if all be good 'twas all mine. There's wit in that now. But this small Poet vents none but his own, and his by whose care
and directions this Stage is govern'd, who has for many yeares both in his fathers dayes, and since directed Poets to write & Players to speak, till he traind up these youths here to what they are now. I some of 'em from before they were able to say a grace of two lines long to have more parts in their pates then would fill so many Dry-fats. And to be serious with you, if after all this, by the venemous practise of some, who study nothing more then his destruction, he should faile us, both Poets and Players would be at losse in Reputation. But this is from our Poet agen, who tels you plainly all the helps he has or desires; And let me tell you he has made prety merry Jigges that ha' pleas'd a many. As (le'me see) th' Antipodes, and (oh I shall never forget) Tom Hoyden o' Tanton Deane. Hee'l bring him hither very shortly in a new Motion, and in a new paire o' slops and new nether-stocks as briske as a Body-lowse in a new Pasture.

quote.l: Meane while, if you like this, or not, why so?
You may be pleas 'to clap at parting tho'.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
